componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from Jason Bazinet with Citi.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just had one question regarding your commentary about your interest and other Cable properties. Can you just give us a sense of what it was about the Bresnan properties that struck you sort of unique in the marketplace relative to what you're seeing now?
componenttext: Just had one question regarding your commentary about your interest and other Cable properties. Can you just give us a sense of what it was about the Bresnan properties that struck you sort of unique in the marketplace relative to what you're seeing now? In other words, was it the non-recourse debt or was it something more about the underlying potential of those properties relative to what they are generating either in terms of revenue or cash flow?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jason, as we looked at the Bresnan acquisition, I think we saw a number of attributes which were especially attractive. The plant had been operated. I think that we saw marketing opportunities. And really, they bring our management team to bear on what we
componenttext: Jason, as we looked at the Bresnan acquisition, I think we saw a number of attributes which were especially attractive. The plant had been operated. I think that we saw marketing opportunities. And really, they bring our management team to bear on what we saw as essentially underpenetrated assets. That's the operating side. And then I'll peg you with the financial side in a second, and Tom may want to add something to the operating side. On the financial side, the non-recourse debt certainly was available to us at roughly, let's call it, 6x AOCF. I think in today's market, that those types of conditions still exist. One unique attribute of the transaction is that we were able to get an asset step up, which provides us with tax shield going forward. And as we looked at that tax shield, we felt that it both reduced the effect of purchase price to us and it reduced, in effect, the amount of equity that we were ultimately committing to the transaction. So we had a little bit of a perfect storm in terms of very attractive financing markets, attractive properties and attractive tax attributes, which made Bresnan, in particular, we think a very special transaction. The properties that we see from time to time in the marketplace really just haven't come up to that level of attractiveness, but we continue to look. And we're hopeful we'll see something that matches that quality at some point in the future. Tom, I don't know if you wanted to add anything?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think that that's a full explanation. The thing that was interesting about Bresnan financially and operationally at the cash flow per home passed, which is the ultimate question of performance in a business, this kind of business, there is typical.
componenttext: No, I think that that's a full explanation. The thing that was interesting about Bresnan financially and operationally at the cash flow per home passed, which is the ultimate question of performance in a business, this kind of business, there is typical. And we think that it's possible to move that cash flow per home passed by increasing penetration. And so it was an attractive property from a financial perspective, but operationally, it's very attractive regardless of how it's financed and an opportunity to create value.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: The next question is from the line of Craig Moffett with Bernstein.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could just detail a little bit the CapEx impact you mentioned from the RS-DVR. And then what kind of impact on the Fox retrans dispute had quantitatively on the cyber metrics that you had in the quarter?
componenttext: I wonder if you could just detail a little bit the CapEx impact you mentioned from the RS-DVR. And then what kind of impact on the Fox retrans dispute had quantitatively on the cyber metrics that you had in the quarter?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, on the RS-DVR, as we've said previously, it allows us to take our existing set-top boxes and essentially by downloading software to the already deployed boxes turn them into a DVR. So in a house today, which we typically have less than two DVR
componenttext: Sure. Well, on the RS-DVR, as we've said previously, it allows us to take our existing set-top boxes and essentially by downloading software to the already deployed boxes turn them into a DVR. So in a house today, which we typically have less than two DVRs per home, significantly less than two DVRs per home, we can tear in all of the set-top boxes in the home into a DVR through this technology. We can buy storage at a lower unit cost per gigabit stored centrally than we can through distributed products like physical DVRs and we have a better business model in terms of doing upgrades. We can upgrade subscribers electronically without doing a physical trip. So it has a significant impact, not only on capital, but ultimately on operating costs for the business. With regard to the retrans, it had an impact in the fourth quarter that was significant. As you know, we were growing subs in the first and second quarter, although the economy was still impacting the business in household formation and that really hasn't changed. Third quarter, which is our seasonally weakest quarter, we did lose video customers. In the fourth quarter, we think that almost all of the either decreased sales or disconnects, which are about 50/50, results from the retrans bite. And as we look at our data after that, the activity of the business is tracking like it was prior to that issue so...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: So given that, Tom, do you feel like the fourth quarter numbers are an anomaly then in terms of subscribers? Or do you have any change in your optimism about the growth prospects of the business overall?
componenttext: So given that, Tom, do you feel like the fourth quarter numbers are an anomaly then in terms of subscribers? Or do you have any change in your optimism about the growth prospects of the business overall?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's an anomaly. Directly related to that, it was a decision we had to take. We were faced with a take it or leave it situation on a very expensive programming cost. We got significantly lower programming costs as a result of it. Our passings rema
componenttext: I think it's an anomaly. Directly related to that, it was a decision we had to take. We were faced with a take it or leave it situation on a very expensive programming cost. We got significantly lower programming costs as a result of it. Our passings remain the same, so our opportunity for sales continues. Our assets remain the same. So we thought that taking the hit was worth it, but we thought it was a onetime kind of hit.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And sorry, just to circle back on the RS-DVR question, mine was more of a housekeeping question. Just could you quantify how much the readiness CapEx was in the quarter just to make sure we understand the numbers?
componenttext: And sorry, just to circle back on the RS-DVR question, mine was more of a housekeeping question. Just could you quantify how much the readiness CapEx was in the quarter just to make sure we understand the numbers?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to break it out specifically, but if you look at our scalable infrastructure and our support infrastructure, our RS-DVR costs went into that. And there is, as I've said previously, a certain quantity of storage and capability that you have t
componenttext: I'm not going to break it out specifically, but if you look at our scalable infrastructure and our support infrastructure, our RS-DVR costs went into that. And there is, as I've said previously, a certain quantity of storage and capability that you have to deploy before you can go to market. We expect to growth going forward in CapEx to be more directly related to actual growth.

componenttext: So if we think about sort of the cost per set-top box, there's no longer, obviously, the hard drive. Everything is HD capable, don't have downloadable. Now it's downloadable security. I mean, you could be down to within a reasonable period of time, $50 per box regardless of what the service is, right?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, if we stayed at historic capabilities in boxes, the cost curve would move us toward that number. So the issue is what kind of boxes we'll buy, and we think that each box we buy is incrementally less than previous boxes even if we increase the capaci
componenttext: Well, if we stayed at historic capabilities in boxes, the cost curve would move us toward that number. So the issue is what kind of boxes we'll buy, and we think that each box we buy is incrementally less than previous boxes even if we increase the capacity of them. So our CPE cost per box is going to be down, whether it'll get to $50 or not, I'm not sure, it depends on what we go with in terms of capability.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, you actually called out advanced advertising this quarter, and I'm just wondering if you could discuss what kind of premium you get versus traditional advertising. And of the customers that you have, the advertisers, how many of them tend to renew fo
componenttext: Tom, you actually called out advanced advertising this quarter, and I'm just wondering if you could discuss what kind of premium you get versus traditional advertising. And of the customers that you have, the advertisers, how many of them tend to renew for this type of product?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to break that out financially, but it is becoming a more meaningful piece of business. We are getting incremental customers that we didn't have previously because they want to buy the capability. And we're getting existing customers to
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to break that out financially, but it is becoming a more meaningful piece of business. We are getting incremental customers that we didn't have previously because they want to buy the capability. And we're getting existing customers to pay us more per spot. Therefore, we're getting a premium from existing customers in terms of capability and both of those categories are growing.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just one separate topic, on TV Everywhere, outside of the home, do you have to pay programmers with more? Are they asking for more for these rights? And in general, what's the willingness of the content companies to go this route? And I guess lik
componenttext: And then just one separate topic, on TV Everywhere, outside of the home, do you have to pay programmers with more? Are they asking for more for these rights? And in general, what's the willingness of the content companies to go this route? And I guess like it's kind of the addendum. Will you be able to charge customers anymore?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the answer to that is each programmer has a different philosophy. You see various programmers talking about TV Everywhere, and I used the word TV Everywhere-like services. Companies may want, as part of their philosophy, serving more custome
componenttext: Well, I think the answer to that is each programmer has a different philosophy. You see various programmers talking about TV Everywhere, and I used the word TV Everywhere-like services. Companies may want, as part of their philosophy, serving more customers, programming companies may want to have programming distributed both on cable and the Internet when they have a customer relationship with a distributor like Cablevision. And we have the technical capability of doing that. Our applications that we're currently deploying don't do that. When you think about VOD, a movie company, you'd certainly want to be able to monetize video-on-demand transactionally in the home and out of the home. And so there's an opportunity to make money outside the home and to charge for it. There are other programming models that will work outside the home as well for programmers, and I think there are a series of opportunities there that we need to explore mutually with programmers and create new value propositions. So you can look at it as a value-add product, which is what TV Everywhere is. Make sure your customer has the content that they’ve purchased from you everywhere they need it or want it, or you can look at it as an adds-on service that creates additional buying opportunities. And I think both of those models will work.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, can you talk a little bit at how you look at your router wireless strategy with WiFi, which obviously is going very well, relative to what Verizon is now doing on LTE in both the residential and the business market from a competitive dynamic? How do
componenttext: Tom, can you talk a little bit at how you look at your router wireless strategy with WiFi, which obviously is going very well, relative to what Verizon is now doing on LTE in both the residential and the business market from a competitive dynamic? How do you think about those product positioning data, voice at sending video, et cetera? And then just also on the product front, I think Time Warner Cable at CES demoed with Samsung service set-top box less world of delivering an IT stream of the linear the channel lineup directly to a television set. I think they think there's an opportunity to do more with the guide, et cetera, in that environment. Do you see that as an interesting opportunity as well? I know you're already encoding IT, but I'm thinking it's sort of as a direct to the television approach.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'll take that last piece first. Interestingly, when you think about an iPad app, it is wireless in the house. 70% of our customers have wireless WiFi installed in their house today. And as I said earlier in my comments, we're the largest provi
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'll take that last piece first. Interestingly, when you think about an iPad app, it is wireless in the house. 70% of our customers have wireless WiFi installed in their house today. And as I said earlier in my comments, we're the largest provider of outdoor WiFi of any distributor in the country. So customers have lots of devices both in the home and out of home that can use WiFi. WiFi has the capability of being higher capacity in terms of speed than the 4G networks currently being deployed. And as you know, with the AT&T's experience, the existing cellular networks have a hard time managing data on the devices the way customers want to use it. And WiFi is an adjunct to that and allows our relationship with the customer to improve their wireless service. As we put our products in IP, if you think about television on an Apple device or an iPad or any Android device in the home, the device is acting as a television. It's acting as a set-top box simultaneously. New TVs being sold have IP inputs into them. And so because we've now put our whole product in IP for in-home distribution and we're capable of putting it out of the home too technically, we have the ability to serve TVs without set-top boxes. So to the extent the processing power in TV is capable of taking our signal and acting as a set-top box, we'll probably develop that application with television vendors, like you saw demoed at CES. And I think it's an opportunity further to get out of the hardware purchasing business at the CPE level. I think we'll be buying CPE for years to come, but the trends are toward the customer having that integrated into their devices.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: The next question is from Richard Greenfield with BTIG.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: One on the retrans battle in terms of could you give some type of quantification of the AOCF hit in the quarter? I assume there was both marketing expense and also costs related to dealing with the actual negotiation. If you could quantify that, that woul
componenttext: One on the retrans battle in terms of could you give some type of quantification of the AOCF hit in the quarter? I assume there was both marketing expense and also costs related to dealing with the actual negotiation. If you could quantify that, that would be great. And then two, Tom, I think you said that the basics of loss was basically all due to the retrans battle as you look at it. Could you give us some sense of what the flow through was for most of those losses of basic subscribers? Triple play subscribers, was it in line with your regular mix? Anyway of thinking about the impact on digital data telephony would be great.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, as you know, our data and voice grew and our video declined, so our triple play increased. So that pended to an aggregate lose video-only customers. Our costs, while I don't want to break them out, we were spending a lot of money on marketing,
componenttext: Sure. Well, as you know, our data and voice grew and our video declined, so our triple play increased. So that pended to an aggregate lose video-only customers. Our costs, while I don't want to break them out, we were spending a lot of money on marketing, buying full-page newspaper ads and alerting our customers. And that had the added effect of drowning out our other marketing messages, which we're not getting out. So you had an effect where we did lose. We had some disconnects, people switching to other services, but we also stepped on our own sales message and grew less customers than we would have. And so I do think, in that sense, it's a kind of a onetime event.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: Is there no way to think what the impact would've been on AOCF? I mean, in terms of what you would've grown in that 1.7% in a more normalized environment?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011

componenttext: I'd say on Bresnan, we're optimistic. I think our due diligence was good. And obviously, we found things we didn't know, but they're both positive, more positive than negative. And our ability to sell products effectively and to take an existing workforce and train them into our methods for selling appear to be working, and we've already seen positive results. With regard to MTA, that is still pending and so there's nothing new to report on.

componenttext: Marci, I did on Bresnan, we took a charge during the fourth quarter relating to the termination of a contract on the telephony side. And I think as Tom mentioned in his comments earlier on today, that was something that we did because it improves for us as a significant net present value for us with Bresnan. So I think that's probably the only thing that I'm not certain we knew we were going to do when we entered into the transaction, but it's something that made a lot of economic sense for us to do. And they had obviously came entirely in the fourth quarter of this year.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And with regard to CES, it is true that we can put our product in IP, which is a protocol, not the Internet, and serve TVs with a Cable TV service. And I think the thing that you have to keep in mind is the Cable Television is a closed network by definiti
componenttext: And with regard to CES, it is true that we can put our product in IP, which is a protocol, not the Internet, and serve TVs with a Cable TV service. And I think the thing that you have to keep in mind is the Cable Television is a closed network by definition. It has a different copyright structure than the Internet and different rights structure. And the new TVs are an opportunity to provide Cable TV on the TV more efficiently. Cable TV has an obligation to customers for privacy in terms of how they’re using that. And generally, we'll be not in an open browser situation. Customers need to have security with regard to their viewing, and the Cable TV applications need to be encapsulated from a security perspective.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, on the RS-DVR, can you talk a little bit about how you're thinking of pricing strategy both now and going forward in terms of the options delivered to the customers? And secondly, as you've been renewing your programming context and particul
componenttext: First of all, on the RS-DVR, can you talk a little bit about how you're thinking of pricing strategy both now and going forward in terms of the options delivered to the customers? And secondly, as you've been renewing your programming context and particularly the broadcast contracts, are you incorporating features so that you can, the storage you have to put in at the head end is driven by actually the number of streams needed rather than to have to put in large numbers of duplicate copies to have one for every customers recording it? And secondly, on the buyback, if you just give us an idea of just directionally what drove the material acceleration first half of the quarter. I know it's not an indication going forward, but what changed your mind set between back half of, say, 4Q '10 and first half of this quarter?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, with regard to RS-DVR, we're currently pricing the exact same as a physical DVR is priced, and we're using it. Essentially, it's the product we go to market with in the service areas where we've rolled it out. The interesting thing about the technol
componenttext: Well, with regard to RS-DVR, we're currently pricing the exact same as a physical DVR is priced, and we're using it. Essentially, it's the product we go to market with in the service areas where we've rolled it out. The interesting thing about the technology is it does allow us to think about pricing differently going forward. We haven't done that yet. We're still in the rollout phase, but we could do free previews of DVR. We could do a very limited storage by programming, include buy programs and include that as part of another package. We could expand the storage capability and sell that as an incremental price opportunity for us and for customers. And so there are a variety of ways of looking at the DVR that is currently in the market and breaking that into various components and selling it even for less or for more depending on how you put it together. So we're excited about the opportunities and the flexibility the RS-DVR model gives us. For instance, if we want to double the capacity of every DVR in the system, we can do that would just by buying the storage essentially. The second part of your question though talks about how much storage do we actually need. We have not entered into single copy contracts with programmers, but it is an opportunity for us and for programmers to use the DVR technology in a way that would make it more efficient for us, essentially an opportunity for the programmer either from an advertising perspective or how their programming is featured perspective. And so there's more to come on the whole RS-DVR infrastructure in terms of the opportunities it creates for us. But it gives us a lot of flexibility. And, Gregg, do you want to talk about the buyback?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. And in terms of the buyback, we continue to see an attractive opportunity in the stock this quarter. And additionally, one of the things we've talked about in prior conference calls is the fact that we are targeting a leverage ratio for the company
componenttext: Sure. And in terms of the buyback, we continue to see an attractive opportunity in the stock this quarter. And additionally, one of the things we've talked about in prior conference calls is the fact that we are targeting a leverage ratio for the company between 4x and 5x. And as we look forward to the Rainbow distribution of $1.25 billion coming into Cablevision at some point, hopefully in the first half of this year, we are endeavoring to keep our leverage within its target range. But again, as I pointed out earlier, no one should read anything specific until one particular quarter's increase or decrease in the share repurchase program. There are lots of factors that go into those decisions, but I can say that the Board and management is happy with the results of the share repurchase program to date. And that's one of the reasons we have had the authorization increase as of this morning.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Pat Armstrong, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike H
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike Huseby, Chief Financial Officer; Joshua Sapan, President and CEO of Rainbow Media; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President. 
Following a discussion of the company's first quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. Please take note of the following: today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. 
Let me point out that on Page, of today's earnings release we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of adjusted operating cash flow or AOCF to operating income. I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results wer
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results were impacted by the addition of Bresnan, as well as transaction costs associated with the Rainbow spin off. Without these items, revenue growth would've been 3% while AOCF growth would have been 4%. 
Our plans to spinoff Rainbow are moving forward nicely. In March, we received the favorable letter ruling from the IRS and plan and preparation to continue according to our schedule. The company also continues to make progress on other initiatives to enhance shareholder value. In a few minutes, Tom will talk more about the initial steps we're taking to incorporate our operational practices into the properties. While it's still early, they are off to a solid start and we're looking forward to the prospects from this acquisition. 
the operating performance of our core business now includes Bresnan, combined with our declining capital spending has resulted in a very strong free cash flow. For the first 3 months of 2011, Cablevision generated more than $290 million in free cash flow, a 22% increase over the prior year. Even without the contribution from the Bresnan properties, free cash flow would have increased 13%. 
The company remained active in buy buying back stock in the first quarter. In addition, after increasing our quarterly dividend to $0.125 last May, I'm pleased to announce that our Board of Directors has approved another increase to $0.15 per quarter. This increase demonstrates our continued confidence in the company's consistent operating performance and stronger balance sheet. 
We are very placed with our performance during the first 3 months of this year. We work hard to ensure that Cablevision's growth continues. Now I would like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter with revenue growth of 50% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter with revenue growth of 50% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF growth, 4%. Cablevision gained 6,000 customers in the quarter. customers increased by 32,000, voice lines by 40,000 and video declined by 8,000. The Bresnan component of those gains, 6,000 subscribers, 10,000 data customers, 6,000 voice lines and 1,000 video customers. 
For the Cablevision core properties average revenue per subscriber was $152.27, reflecting a sequential increase of $1.59. With the inclusion of the Bresnan properties, our total RPS for the first quarter was $149.75. While we've owned Bresnan properties for just over 4 months, we are beginning to make significant progress in incorporating our operating tactics in these systems. 
As of May 12, Optimum branded services will be sold throughout the former Bresnan footprint and the Bresnan brand will be retired. We've restructured our field and sales forces and practices consistent with the core operation. We will complete a transport ring at year end, which 85% of our western customers will be connected to. We will run these geographically separate locations as one large cable system. 
We're aggressively offering our fully featured voice prior to capitalize on the currently low phone penetration in these properties, as well as on high-speed products offered by our competition, the high-priced products offered by our competition. We are increasing the speeds of the high-speed data service to our current Optimum Online and Optimum boost speeds. We're taking a number of high-definition channels to over 100 and we're aggressively promoting the triple play. As these initiatives are being rolled out in the west, Cablevision continues to enhance its products and services in the. 
On May 1, we announced the introduction of the ultimate triple play for $100 per month. For the first year, customers will receive the original triple play products with enhancements. These include Boost Plus, our new high-speed service at 50 megabits downstream, 8 megabits upstream; new in-home Wi-Fi router; and Optimum Link, our new PC to TV relay service. This package will be attractive for many reasons: price, the super high-speed data service with a router and the capability of our customers to deal with what is on their PC screens on all their televisions acting as monitors. 
Our RS-DVR service, DVR Plus, has now been rolled out to Connecticut. Customer base in the near future will be launched in Brooklyn. Our new iPad app, where customers can view their full Cable Television service on their iPad acting as an in-home television, has been well received. Our interactive advanced advertising products continue to be enhanced. In April, we had 84 different interactive campaigns providing advertisers with a wide variety of ways to reach the customers. 
Cable capital spending totaled $107 million in the first quarter. As a percentage of cable revenue, capital spending was 7.2% for the first quarter. We said in the past that our expectation was to begin seen declines in capital spending and capital intensity as we stop purchasing physical DVRs and purchased fewer and less expensive digital set-top. First quarter is typically our lightest spending quarter. Nonetheless, 2011 full year capital spending even with the Bresnan initiative, expected to be below that of 2010, which do not include Bresnan. 
Turning to LightPath. LightPath has had a great quarter with revenue growth of 13% and AOCF growth of 26%. LightPath fiber network is now connected to almost 4,600. Revenue derived from ethernet services in the first quarter grew by 28% versus the prior year. And for the 13th consecutive year, LightPath has been commended for excellent service by the New York State Public Service Commission. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Josh Sapan, who will discuss Rainbow's results

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represents a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $10
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represents a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $100 million. The vast majority of the revenue growth came from our national networks, primarily driven by the strong performance of our original programming, this was our second consecutive quarter of double-digit add revenue growth. 
Add revenue for our national networks was up 15% in the quarter compared with the prior year period as we saw ratings increases for both AMC and WE tv during the quarter, particularly in prime time. IFC, which is know an ad supported network contributed to that growth as well. And our national networks affiliate revenue grew by 4% in the quarter versus last year, a combination of increased license fees and increased subscribers. 
Operating expenses in the quarter for the national networks grew up by roughly 11% or $14 million, largely due to increased marketing and promotion of original series on IFC and WE tv to a lesser extent, increased programming costs at AMC. Despite this increase of operating expenses, the national networks' adjusted operating cash flow increased 6% or $6 million to $106 million versus the prior year period. As we continue to introduce new original series at each of our networks over the coming year, we'll continue to incur additional programming and marketing costs to support those shows. 
At AMC, The Killing, our latest dramatic original series, premiered Sunday, April 3, with 2.7 million viewers tuning in to the 2-hour debut. This was AMC's second highest rated original series ever with the exception of last fall's breakout hit, called The Walking Dead. 
Later this year, the network will premiere season 4 of our series, Breaking Bad. And even 2 of the Walking Dead and our new original series called, Hell on Wheels, which tells the story of the building of a transcontinental railroad. And we're pleased to have noted 2 series of Mad Men locked in with season 5 set to air in early 2012. 
In other programming businesses, which primarily include our international distribution and IFC Entertainment, our phone distribution business, revenue grew by 28% or $5 million to $25 million and AOCF improved by 19% or $2 million to an AOCF loss of $7 million. Contributing to the AOCF loss were ongoing boom HD litigated expenses pertaining to additional lawsuit. We're pleased with the results for the quarter. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Gregg Siebert, who will briefly cover the company's overall financials.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter the Company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage ra
componenttext:
Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter the Company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.6x. The CSC Holdings Group, Restricted Group leverage ratio was 3.8x. But subsequent to the end of the quarter, we repaid CSC Holdings 7 5/8 senior notes in the amount of $326 million using cash on hand and borrowings under our revolver. Following that repayment, the outstanding balance on our revolver was up $1 billion. Currently, Rainbow National Services has $1.1 billion of debt and $580 million available on its revolving credit facility. The ratio under its unleveraged was 2.4x as of March 31. We continue to make good progress on the upcoming spinoff of Rainbow or AMC Networks Inc. We recently received an IRS Private Letter Ruling confirming the spin-off of Cablevision and the Cablevision shareholders. In addition, we are in the midst of a Form-10 review process with the SEC and we've reached an agreement with NASDAQ to service the listing exchange for AMC. 
We continue to have discussions with our lenders regarding the financing of the transaction and currently anticipate that AMC's financing structure will consist of a $500 million revolving credit facility, $1 billion in the third loan A facility, $675 million in the term loan B facility and $750 million in unsecured notes. Proceeds from this financing will be used to refinance existing RNS debt, approximately $1.1 billion and to fund a $1.25 billion distribution to either Cablevision or CSC Holdings to repay debt, including the drawn portion of our revolver. 
As part of the Rainbow refinancing, on April 13, RNS issued a notice of redemption to holders of $300 million of 8 7/5 % senior notes due 2012. RNS plans to use cash on hand and availability under its revolver to fund this redemption on May 13. As Jim mentioned, we continue to be on track from a timing perspective and anticipate a midyear closing for the spin. 
Turning to the company's share repurchase program, in the first quarter, we repurchased 6.7 million shares of Cablevision stock at an average price of $35.10 for a total of $234 million. From inception of the program through the end of April, we've repurchased $616 million of CVC stock at an average price of $31.74. We have $384 million of repurchase authorization remaining. 
Finally, as Jim mentioned, our quarterly dividend has been increased for the second consecutive year. The dividend increase from $0.125 to $0.15 per share per quarter will represent a meaningful increase in the yield on Cablevision stock, which of course, will be even greater after the spin off of Rainbow. Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

componenttext: I'll start, Doug. On the subissue, Cablevision core system, the traditional cable system lost about 8,400 video customers. Some of that was attributable I think to how we came into the year after the dispute we had with News Corp. and the Carriage of the World Series. But we still continue to see softness in the economy, particularly in lower income neighborhoods, New York City, Newark, Bridgeport and other parts of our systems are not performing, as well as they have in the past and we think that's due directly to economic factors. And then that continues to be the biggest impact on us on a year-to-year basis.

componenttext: Well, we had reasonably good growth in high-speed data, most of our, a lot of our high-speed data growth is coming from triple play customers. So I would say that the same economic forces affect data growth as they do video growth.

componenttext: This is Josh. Scatter market has been pretty good. As you may have read, as I mentioned, our ratings at AMC and WE tv were up. AMC in sales prime, high single-digit. componenttext: Craig, this is Tom. I guess, yes, FiOS is aggressive, and we are doing well relatively speaking, competitively. They have been offering very aggressive pricing for the triple play contrary to their expressed marketing strategy of being a premium service. But we continue to respond in the marketplace with superior service and superior product offerings. We just launched our new Boost Plus product integrated into a triple play. We've been the first company to put its full cable service on the iPad. The first company to be able to put all of the products on your PC, on all your TVS. So we continue to led in terms of service and quality and product development but it's a very competitive marketplace.

componenttextpreview: The capital intensity number was so much lower than we expected in the Cable business. And given Tom's comment about, it looks like this is sustainable. The Cable business will be generating a huge amount of cash. And I guess can we just return to the per
componenttext: The capital intensity number was so much lower than we expected in the Cable business. And given Tom's comment about, it looks like this is sustainable. The Cable business will be generating a huge amount of cash. And I guess can we just return to the perennial question of acquisitions versus share buybacks some of the spin-off has happened?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, we'll actually used the word, insight in your question so I figured that acquisitions lurks primarily on your mind. Anything as you know, we're not going to comment on speculation regarding any specific potential acquisition. But I will take the opp
componenttext: Sure, we'll actually used the word, insight in your question so I figured that acquisitions lurks primarily on your mind. Anything as you know, we're not going to comment on speculation regarding any specific potential acquisition. But I will take the opportunity to repeat the fact that we are committed and we have a balanced strategic of creating shareholder value. And I think that's pretty evident in what we've accomplished over the past 10 or 11 months. We've not only completed the Bresnan acquisitions but we've also repurchased over $600 million worth of stock entity announced that we've increased the dividend. I think that our leverage targets are going to remain in the range that we've discussed before, which is 4 to 5x, obviously heading in a more toward the 4.5 to 6, range which is kind of the sustainable upper end of that range but we do need flexibility to go higher than that. And we are going to continue to look at acquisition opportunities. Our primary focus in evaluating these have opportunities and I'll use Bresnan as an example is we undertook a rigorous analysis of the company and we look at the operating returns we thought we could generate from that business and the financial structure of the transaction. And at the conclusion of that analysis, we determined that the Bresnan acquisition was going to produce higher returns for our shareholders an alternative uses of capital. Now I want to add that we've looked at other opportunities since Bresnan and we haven't reached that same conclusion for some of the other properties that we've looked at. So I think going forward, that's the type of a pretty intense acquisition analysis that you should expect from us as we look at opportunities there. And again, we intend to keep the leverage within the range we have discussed before and we intend to continue our repurchase program.

componenttext: 2 questions, one on AMC for Josh. When you look at the strong ratings growth and you had very solid revenue growth in the quarter, when we start to see that kind of translate from a profitability standpoint. It is recognize that you're investing in programming and sending lots of shows, how long do you think is it when the upfront kicks in, in September and October? Were are we actually to see the earnings and free cash flow benefit coming out of all the success you've had from the national networks and ratings? And then I know it's a minor point but it looks like it's just a problem asset. News, you don't break out anymore. Last year, you did $1 million in profit. I assume the revenue declines. It's now losing money. Is there anything you can do beyond shutting down Newsday to limit the impact it has on kind of core Cablevision?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Josh. We, our original program is scripted material. It began about 5 years ago with Mad Men. And we have been carefully adding to that along the way, we had Breaking Bad. As you know and last quarter, The Walking Dead in this quarter and Th
componenttext: Sure, this is Josh. We, our original program is scripted material. It began about 5 years ago with Mad Men. And we have been carefully adding to that along the way, we had Breaking Bad. As you know and last quarter, The Walking Dead in this quarter and The Killing, our growth through that period of time has been strong. So those shows have been working for us in combination with what is substantially still across the number of hours today of the movie service. So the economic productivity of it is already in evidence over the past 4 years performance. It continues to get stronger as we add more volume and success today in our original. We think we have an opportunity to advertisers and we are seeing higher CPMs so we think that trend will continue and get better, but it's already in effect.

componenttext: Well, I think it's fairly small and I think we're subject to seasonality so I don't think it's a particular trend that we'll see.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And with regard to Newsday, we really have 2 strategies with Newsday. One, we'd like it to be a profitable business as a stand-alone business. But it's also an integral part of our localism strategy as a cable operator. So Optimum Online customers have ac
componenttext: And with regard to Newsday, we really have 2 strategies with Newsday. One, we'd like it to be a profitable business as a stand-alone business. But it's also an integral part of our localism strategy as a cable operator. So Optimum Online customers have access to Newsday online products as part of their service. But we did successfully negotiate a new labor contract at Newsday recently. And we have taken a rate increase in new stand, which had some negative impact on circulation actual home circulation for Newsday. And so we think its not going to be a drug from and AOCF perspective. And that as we move into the digital world that we can find ways to create new products for Newsday that will drive additional revenue. So we haven't given upon it by any means.

componenttext: Yes, we think we're at the right level now at AMC and WE tv. In the future, it could be done but we are steady state for now.

componenttext: Right, in terms of overall capital spending, customer equipment comes down for 2 reasons: the Network DVR and also, because we went to a downloadable security box. headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the iPad app, do you have plans or the rates to extend that out of the home on to the Wi-Fi footprint for people who are video customers? Secondly, on discussing downloadable security satellite, how does that integrate with say, consumer devices that h
componenttext: On the iPad app, do you have plans or the rates to extend that out of the home on to the Wi-Fi footprint for people who are video customers? Secondly, on discussing downloadable security satellite, how does that integrate with say, consumer devices that have cable card slots. I mean will you be able to take advantage of Samsung TV, who is going to have cable card system that would be no set-top box, would you knead a set-top box for those going forward? And third if you can just give us an idea how much of the video challenge you are seeing? Is it a matter of lower take rates in the home versus just a lower number of occupied homes out of the actual home path?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the latter question is there's definitely less occupied housing per home passed than there was in prior periods. And that is a significant factor in our growth prospects for video. The first part of your question, the iPad application that we curr
componenttext: I think the latter question is there's definitely less occupied housing per home passed than there was in prior periods. And that is a significant factor in our growth prospects for video. The first part of your question, the iPad application that we currently have deployed turns your iPad into a television in the home and it becomes an additional outlet that has the full cable TV service on it. And that is consistent with our existing in home Cable Television price that we've negotiated with everyone. To put it on a Wi-Fi network, which we could do technically with these would require new license agreements. Some of the programmers that we're dealing with have been given us TV Everywhere-type rates and go rights, which are Internet rates. And we are taking advantage of those rights and creating additional products outside the home. With regard to the Wi-Fi, the Wi-Fi network is an Internet service but it's controlled by us and it's for the benefit of our customers. So it actually creates another space for us to exploit and create value for our customers should we choose to. We have not sought those rights today or at least deployed them. The downloadable security question, of how do we handle existing cable card slots, we still have a problem with the cable card in that it's a one-way service. And so to build a 2-way interactive service, which makes our full product functional, a set-top box is required. However, there's a whole new generation of televisions being developed, which are like the iPad in terms of their capabilities but bigger in the sense that they have a lot of processing power that they would hang on a wall. Those TVs if you think about the iPad, the iPad is actually a TV with a set-top box built into it with software. Televisions being deployed on walls, like Samsung's new smart TVs, are actually capable of having a virtual set-top box built into them in the same way that an iPad is. So capital intensity will go down as a result of that kind of deployment once you get your network architected like we are, which is a network capable of serving every kind of device in the home.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's been so much talk about LTEs so I'm just curious how Wi-Fi is going for you both as a retention tool and as an acquisition tool. So how are you and current customers responding? And then a question for Greg. I think you said leverage at consolidat
componenttext: There's been so much talk about LTEs so I'm just curious how Wi-Fi is going for you both as a retention tool and as an acquisition tool. So how are you and current customers responding? And then a question for Greg. I think you said leverage at consolidated Cablevision was 4.6x, which is it at the highend of your target and an increase from last quarter so any thoughts on your leverage or debt profile post the Rainbow spin and where you maybe levered?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start first, if you don't mind. In terms of leverage, we're up this quarter because we repurchased additional stock and we funded it through our revolver. And the comments relating to the distribution from Rainbow, specific about the fact that we wou
componenttext: I'll start first, if you don't mind. In terms of leverage, we're up this quarter because we repurchased additional stock and we funded it through our revolver. And the comments relating to the distribution from Rainbow, specific about the fact that we would expect a portion, the funded portion of our revolver to be repaid as a result of the Rainbow transaction. That doesn't provide additional debt capacity for us. What it does is it just in effect, takes our revolver, pays it off and transfers a lot of that debt over to Rainbow. So I think that you can look at some of what has occurred this quarter as being positioning for the ultimate Rainbow spin-off. I do expect our leverage to come down next quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: With regard to Wi-Fi and retention and the value customers, our objective is to get our customers to use the Wi-Fi network, which they are doing in increasing amounts everyday. The Wi-Fi network is faster and more capable than LTE network in bulk, so it's
componenttext: With regard to Wi-Fi and retention and the value customers, our objective is to get our customers to use the Wi-Fi network, which they are doing in increasing amounts everyday. The Wi-Fi network is faster and more capable than LTE network in bulk, so it's really 5 G, not 4G. And in terms of retention people who do use our Wi-Fi network have lower churn rates than those who don't. So we think it's a valuable retention tool and ultimately, an acquisition tool as well.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bryan Kraft of Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bryan Kraft of Evercore Partners.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, just so we can clarify your comments on the economy. Are you saying that you believe the economic conditions in your footprint are more challenging now than they were say a year ago? Or are you making comparisons back to pre-credit crisis conditions?
componenttext: Tom, just so we can clarify your comments on the economy. Are you saying that you believe the economic conditions in your footprint are more challenging now than they were say a year ago? Or are you making comparisons back to pre-credit crisis conditions? And then I just have one other question were there integration costs in the quarter related to Bresnan? And how do you see kind of upside to margin in the year playing out as Bresnan becomes more fully integrated?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of the economy, housing occupation -- occupied housing as a percentage of all housing is still declining. So you have the effects of the economy bringing themselves out in people actually leaving their homes, leaving their apartment, moving
componenttext: Well, in terms of the economy, housing occupation -- occupied housing as a percentage of all housing is still declining. So you have the effects of the economy bringing themselves out in people actually leaving their homes, leaving their apartment, moving in with each other and that has -- and that is worse year-over-year. I think ultimately, it stabilizes but there are still a significant number of people who are unemployed and running out of money. In terms of margins, I can't really speculate on the impact of Bresnan on margins. It's just about 10% of our business and we are going to ramp that business up this year. And so, I don't think you'll see a significant material impact as a result of that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Brian, one thing you'll see in the first quarter as we did have approximately $8 million worth of spinoffs associated with the AMC spend. And so that's one item that is not going to be a repeat in after the spin takes place.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Your final question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Starting with Josh, the Form-10 has some interesting discussions about your programming strategy and you want to own more of your content. Now I believe I could be wrong. I think Walking Dead was your first sort of Rainbow produced or AMC produced piece o
componenttext: Starting with Josh, the Form-10 has some interesting discussions about your programming strategy and you want to own more of your content. Now I believe I could be wrong. I think Walking Dead was your first sort of Rainbow produced or AMC produced piece of content and obviously, Mad Men and others, you licensed. Just wondering if you changed the mix over time going forward and what that might mean going back to sort of the investment margin question from earlier today? And then for Tom, I was wondering if there's anything you'd point out that would lead to revenue growth accelerating from cable if you strip out Bresnan, I think in the release you said it was 2% this quarter. It sounds like the economy really holding back units and maybe ARPU as well, just wondering if you think any thing else we should be focused on in terms of reaccelerating the top line?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Josh. We do think related to 410 that the more we can own content and control content, the better off we are if we can do it economically. It gives us the ability if we have greater ownership position and it actually is a spectrum question, it's n
componenttext: This is Josh. We do think related to 410 that the more we can own content and control content, the better off we are if we can do it economically. It gives us the ability if we have greater ownership position and it actually is a spectrum question, it's not you either owned or licensed it, there is sort of steps in between but if we can own increasingly increments then we get the benefit of being able to put it on different platforms, being the beneficiary of its exploitation and subsequent ancillary markets being able to distribute it internationally. We have to date been able to on the nonfiction side, which is more for WE tv and IFC take ownership positions that are more complete. It's a lower price tag to do reality TV or nonfiction, so it's less risky. And so more of the content on that site is owned. But AMC, we're dealing with higher price tags for scripted that you're quite right that we have one series, where we have a significant near-complete ownership position and that's The Walking Dead. We did that because we thought that the nature of the material, which is typically referred to as genre or was less risky than some of the other material that we've traded in and it was a good bet. And it seems to be born out because it was successful and the benefits that I described a moment ago. As we go forward, we would just evaluate each proposition and determine whether the risk profile of the series or show seems to make sense and whether the economics makes sense. So I don't think you'll see anyone particular pattern emerging, it will be opportunistic and it will be case-by-case, where we can own more. It will be sensible, we will.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of revenue drivers, this product that we just launched Boost Plus, this 50-megabit service, which integrates additional functionality like Optimum Link inside that service is a $15 a month product. So it's essentially right on top of our
componenttext: And then in terms of revenue drivers, this product that we just launched Boost Plus, this 50-megabit service, which integrates additional functionality like Optimum Link inside that service is a $15 a month product. So it's essentially right on top of our existing data business. It's a new data tier and we've integrated it into our acquisition strategy. So that will produce incremental revenue per customer going forward and creates an upgrade opportunity to our existing subscriber base to increase revenue per subs as well. We took a very light rate increase this year as we came into the year because of the situation that we had in the fourth quarter. We thought that in the long-run we'd be wiser to how a moderate rate increase this year so we've had that as well. And we sort of complemented were offset that to sum extent going forward with our new revenue drivers as a result of the Boost Plus strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike H
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike Huseby, Chief Financial Officer; Joshua Sapan, President and CEO of Rainbow Media; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President. 
Following a discussion of the company's first quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. Please take note of the following: Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. 
Let me point out that on Page 5 of today's earnings release, we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF, to operating income. I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue, driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results we
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue, driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results were impacted by the addition of Bresnan, as well as transaction costs associated with the Rainbow spin-off. Without these items, revenue growth would've been 3%, while AOCF growth would have been 4%. 
Our plans to spin off Rainbow are moving forward nicely. In March, we received the favorable letter of ruling -- a favorable letter ruling from the IRS, and planning and preparation continue according to our schedule. The company also continues to make progress on its other initiatives to enhance shareholder value. In a few minutes, Tom will talk more about the initial steps we are taking to incorporate our operational practices into the Bresnan properties. While it is still early, they are off to a solid start, and we're looking forward to the prospects from this acquisition. 
The operating performance of our core business, which now includes Bresnan, combined with our declining capital spending, has resulted in a very strong free cash flow. For the first 3 months of 2011, Cablevision generated more than $290 million in free cash flow, a 22% increase over the prior year. Even without the contribution from the Bresnan properties, free cash flow would have increased 13%. 
The company remained active in buying back stock in the first quarter. In addition, after increasing our quarterly dividend to $0.125 last May, I'm pleased to announce that our Board of Directors has approved another increase to $0.15 per quarter. This increase demonstrates our continued confidence in the company's consistent operating performance and stronger balance sheet. 
We are very pleased with our performance during the first 3 months of this year. We will work hard to ensure that Cablevision's growth continues. Now I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter, with revenue growth of 10.9% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter, with revenue growth of 10.9% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF growth 4%. 
Cablevision gained 6,000 customers in the quarter. Data customers increased by 32,000, voice lines by 40,000 and video declined by 8,000. The Bresnan component of those gains: 6,000 subscribers, 10,000 data customers, 6,000 voice lines and 1,000 video customers. 
For the Cablevision core properties, average revenue per subscriber was $152.27, reflecting a sequential increase of $1.59. With the inclusion of the Bresnan properties, our total RPS for the first quarter was $149.75. While we've owned Bresnan properties for just over 4 months, we are beginning to make significant progress in incorporating our operating tactics in these systems. 
As of May 12, Optimum-branded services will be sold throughout the former Bresnan footprint, and the Bresnan brand will be retired. We've restructured our field and sales forces and practices consistent with the core operation. We will complete a transport ring by year end, which 85% of our western customers will be connected to. We will run these geographically separate locations as one large cable system. 
We are aggressively offering our fully featured voice product to capitalize on the currently low phone penetration in these properties, as well as on high-speed products offered by our competition -- the high-priced products offered by our competition. We are increasing the speeds of the high-speed data service to our current Optimum Online and Optimum boost speeds. We're taking a number of high-definition channels to over 100, and we're aggressively promoting the Triple Play. As these initiatives are being rolled out in the west, Cablevision continues to enhance its products and services in the New York area footprint. 
On May 1, we announced the introduction of the ultimate Triple Play for $100 per month. For the first year, customers will receive the original Triple Play products with enhancements. These include Boost Plus, our new high-speed service at 50 megabits downstream and 8 megabits upstream; new in-home Wi-Fi router; and Optimum Link, our new PC to TV relay service. This package will be attractive for many reasons: Price, the super high-speed data service with a router and the capability of our customers to view what is on their PC screens on all their televisions acting as monitors. 
Our RS-DVR service, DVR Plus, has now been rolled out to Connecticut customer base, and in the near future will be launched in Brooklyn. Our new iPad app, where customers can view their full cable television service on their iPad acting as an in-home television, has been well received. Our interactive advanced advertising products continue to be enhanced. In April, we had 84 different interactive campaigns, providing advertisers with a wide variety of ways to reach the customers. 
Cable capital spending totaled $107 million in the first quarter. As a percentage of cable revenue, capital spending was 7.2% for the first quarter. We said in the past that our expectation was to begin seeing declines in capital spending and capital intensity as we've stopped purchasing physical DVRs and purchased fewer and less expensive digital set-top. First quarter is typically our lightest spending quarter. Nonetheless, 2011 full year capital spending, even with the Bresnan initiative, expected to be below that of 2010, which did not include Bresnan. 
Turning to Lightpath. Lightpath has had a great quarter, with revenue growth of 13% and AOCF growth of 26%. Lightpath fiber network is now connected to almost 4,600 [indiscernible]. Revenue derived from ethernet services in the first quarter grew by 28% versus the prior year, and for the 13th consecutive year, Lightpath has been commended for excellent service by the New York State Public Service Commission. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Josh Sapan, who will discuss Rainbow's results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represented a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior-year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $1
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represented a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior-year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $100 million. The vast majority of the revenue growth came from our national networks. Primarily driven by the strong performance of our original programming, this was our seventh consecutive quarter of double-digit ad revenue growth. 
Ad revenue for our national networks was up 15% in the quarter compared with the prior-year period, as we saw ratings increases for both AMC and WE tv during the quarter, particularly in prime time. IFC, which is now an ad-supported network, contributed to that growth as well. And our national networks affiliate revenue grew by 4% in the quarter versus last year, a combination of increased license fees and increased subscribers. 
Operating expenses in the quarter for the national networks were up by roughly 11% or $14 million, largely due to increased marketing and promotion of original series on IFC and WE tv, and to a lesser extent, increased programming costs at AMC. Despite this increase in operating expenses, the national networks' adjusted operating cash flow increased 6% or $6 million to $106 million versus the prior-year period. As we continue to introduce new original series at each of our networks over the coming year, we'll continue to incur additional programming and marketing costs to support those shows. 
At AMC, The Killing, our latest dramatic original series, premiered Sunday, April 3, with 2.7 million viewers tuning in for the 2-hour debut. This was AMC's second highest-rated original series premiere ever with the exception of last fall's breakout hit called The Walking Dead. 
Later this year, the network will premiere season 4 of our series, Breaking Bad; season 2 of the Walking Dead; and our new original series called Hell on Wheels, which tells a story of the building of the transcontinental railroad. And we're pleased to have another 2 series of Mad Men locked in with season 5 set to air in early 2012. 
In Rainbow's other programming businesses, which primarily include our international distribution and IFC Entertainment, our film distribution business, revenue grew by 28% or $5 million to $25 million, and AOCF improved by 19% or $2 million to an AOCF loss of $7 million. Contributing to the AOCF loss were ongoing VOOM HD-related litigated expenses pertaining to this lawsuit. We are pleased with the results for the quarter. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Gregg Siebert, who will briefly cover the company's overall financials.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage r
componenttext:
Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.6x. The CSC Holdings Group and Restricted Group leverage ratio was 3.8x. 
Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we repaid CSC Holdings 7 5/8 senior notes in the amount of $326 million using cash on hand and borrowings under our revolver. Following that repayment, the outstanding balance on our revolver was $1 billion. Currently, Rainbow National Services has $1.1 billion of debt and $580 million available on its revolving credit facility. The ratio under its bond leverage desk [ph] was 2.4x as of March 31. 
We continue to make good progress on the upcoming spin-off of Rainbow or AMC Networks Inc. We recently received an IRS Private Letter Ruling confirming the spin-off of the tax-free Cablevision and the Cablevision shareholders. In addition, we are in the midst of a Form-10 review process with the SEC, and we've reached an agreement with NASDAQ to service the listing exchange for AMC. 
We continue to have discussions with our lenders regarding the financing of the transaction and currently anticipate that AMC's financing structure will consist of a $500 million revolving credit facility, $1 billion in the term loan A facility, $675 million in the term loan B facility and $750 million in unsecured notes. Proceeds from this financing will be used to refinance existing RNS debt, approximately $1.1 billion, and to fund a $1.25 billion distribution to either Cablevision or CSC Holdings to repay debt, including the drawn portion of our revolver. 
As part of the Rainbow refinancing, on April 13, RNS issued a notice of redemption to holders of $300 million of its 8 7/5% senior notes due 2012. RNS plans to use cash on hand and availability under its revolver to fund this redemption on May 13. As Jim mentioned, we continue to be on track from a timing perspective and anticipate a midyear closing for the spin. 
Turning to the company's share repurchase program. In the first quarter, we repurchased 6.7 million shares of Cablevision stock at an average price of $35.10 for a total of $234 million. From inception of the program through the end of April, we've repurchased $616 million of CVC stock at an average price of $31.74. We have $384 million of repurchase authorization remaining. 
Finally, as Jim mentioned, our quarterly dividend has been increased for the second consecutive year. The dividend increase from $0.125 to $0.15 per share per quarter will represent a meaningful increase in the yield on Cablevision stock, which of course, will be even greater after the spin-off of Rainbow. 
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

componenttext: I'll start, Doug. On the sub issue, Cablevision core system, the traditional cable system, lost about 8,400 video customers. Some of that was attributable I think to how we came into the year after the dispute we had had with News Corp. in the carriage of the World Series. But we still continue to see softness in the economy, particularly in lower-income neighborhoods, New York City, Newark, Bridgeport and other parts of our systems, are not performing as well as they have in the past, and we think that's due directly to economic factors. And then that continues to be the biggest impact on us on a year-to-year basis.
