headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the confere
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Pat Armstrong, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike H
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Mike Huseby, Chief Financial Officer; Joshua Sapan, President and CEO of Rainbow Media; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President. 
Following a discussion of the company's first quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. Please take note of the following: Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. 
Let me point out that on Page 5 of today's earnings release, we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF, to operating income. I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue, driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results we
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. Cablevision performed well in the first quarter of 2011. The company reported a 10% increase in revenue, driven by steady growth at our Cable and Rainbow businesses. Meanwhile, AOCF grew 8%. These first quarter results were impacted by the addition of Bresnan, as well as transaction costs associated with the Rainbow spin-off. Without these items, revenue growth would've been 3%, while AOCF growth would have been 4%. 
Our plans to spin off Rainbow are moving forward nicely. In March, we received the favorable letter of ruling -- a favorable letter ruling from the IRS, and planning and preparation continue according to our schedule. The company also continues to make progress on its other initiatives to enhance shareholder value. In a few minutes, Tom will talk more about the initial steps we are taking to incorporate our operational practices into the Bresnan properties. While it is still early, they are off to a solid start, and we're looking forward to the prospects from this acquisition. 
The operating performance of our core business, which now includes Bresnan, combined with our declining capital spending, has resulted in a very strong free cash flow. For the first 3 months of 2011, Cablevision generated more than $290 million in free cash flow, a 22% increase over the prior year. Even without the contribution from the Bresnan properties, free cash flow would have increased 13%. 
The company remained active in buying back stock in the first quarter. In addition, after increasing our quarterly dividend to $0.125 last May, I'm pleased to announce that our Board of Directors has approved another increase to $0.15 per quarter. This increase demonstrates our continued confidence in the company's consistent operating performance and stronger balance sheet. 
We are very pleased with our performance during the first 3 months of this year. We will work hard to ensure that Cablevision's growth continues. Now I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter, with revenue growth of 10.9% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. The Telecom business delivered a solid quarter, with revenue growth of 10.9% and AOCF growth of 10% when compared to last year's first quarter. Without the impact of the Bresnan properties, revenue growth was 3% and AOCF growth 4%. 
Cablevision gained 6,000 customers in the quarter. Data customers increased by 32,000, voice lines by 40,000 and video declined by 8,000. The Bresnan component of those gains: 6,000 subscribers, 10,000 data customers, 6,000 voice lines and 1,000 video customers. 
For the Cablevision core properties, average revenue per subscriber was $152.27, reflecting a sequential increase of $1.59. With the inclusion of the Bresnan properties, our total RPS for the first quarter was $149.75. While we've owned Bresnan properties for just over 4 months, we are beginning to make significant progress in incorporating our operating tactics in these systems. 
As of May 12, Optimum-branded services will be sold throughout the former Bresnan footprint, and the Bresnan brand will be retired. We've restructured our field and sales forces and practices consistent with the core operation. We will complete a transport ring by year end, which 85% of our western customers will be connected to. We will run these geographically separate locations as one large cable system. 
We are aggressively offering our fully featured voice product to capitalize on the currently low phone penetration in these properties, as well as on high-speed products offered by our competition -- the high-priced products offered by our competition. We are increasing the speeds of the high-speed data service to our current Optimum Online and Optimum boost speeds. We're taking the number of high-definition channels to over 100, and we're aggressively promoting the Triple Play. As these initiatives are being rolled out in the west, Cablevision continues to enhance its products and services in the New York area footprint. 
On May 1, we announced the introduction of the ultimate Triple Play for $100 per month. For the first year, customers will receive the original Triple Play products with enhancements. These include Boost Plus, our new high-speed service at 50 megabits downstream and 8 megabits upstream; new in-home Wi-Fi router; and Optimum Link, our new PC to TV relay service. This package will be attractive for many reasons: Price, the super high-speed data service with a router and the capability of our customers to view what is on their PC screens on all their televisions acting as monitors. 
Our RS-DVR service, DVR Plus, has now been rolled out to Connecticut customer base, and in the near future will be launched in Brooklyn. Our new iPad app, where customers can view their full cable television service on their iPad acting as an in-home television, has been well received. Our interactive advanced advertising products continue to be enhanced. In April, we had 84 different interactive campaigns, providing advertisers with a wide variety of ways to reach the customers. 
Cable capital spending totaled $107 million in the first quarter. As a percentage of cable revenue, capital spending was 7.2% for the first quarter. We said in the past that our expectation was to begin seeing declines in capital spending and capital intensity as we've stopped purchasing physical DVRs and purchased fewer and less expensive digital set-top. First quarter is typically our lightest spending quarter. Nonetheless, 2011 full year capital spending, even with the Bresnan initiative, expected to be below that of 2010, which did not include Bresnan. 
Turning to Lightpath. Lightpath has had a great quarter, with revenue growth of 13% and AOCF growth of 26%. Lightpath fiber network is now connected to almost 4,600 [indiscernible]. Revenue derived from ethernet services in the first quarter grew by 28% versus the prior year, and for the 13th consecutive year, Lightpath has been commended for excellent service by the New York State Public Service Commission. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Josh Sapan, who will discuss Rainbow's results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represented a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior-year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $1
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Tom. Rainbow's first quarter revenue of $273 million represented a 10% or $25 million increase over the prior-year's first quarter. Operating expenses increased 11% or $17 million and AOCF improved 8% or $8 million versus prior year to $100 million. The vast majority of the revenue growth came from our national networks. Primarily driven by the strong performance of our original programming, this was our seventh consecutive quarter of double-digit ad revenue growth. 
Ad revenue for our national networks was up 15% in the quarter compared with the prior-year period, as we saw ratings increases for both AMC and WE tv during the quarter, particularly in prime time. IFC, which is now an ad-supported network, contributed to that growth as well. And our national networks affiliate revenue grew by 4% in the quarter versus last year, a combination of increased license fees and increased subscribers. 
Operating expenses in the quarter for the national networks were up by roughly 11% or $14 million, largely due to increased marketing and promotion of original series on IFC and WE tv, and to a lesser extent, increased programming costs at AMC. Despite this increase in operating expenses, the national networks' adjusted operating cash flow increased 6% or $6 million to $106 million versus the prior-year period. As we continue to introduce new original series at each of our networks over the coming year, we'll continue to incur additional programming and marketing costs to support those shows. 
At AMC, The Killing, our latest dramatic original series, premiered Sunday, April 3, with 2.7 million viewers tuning in for the 2-hour debut. This was AMC's second highest-rated original series premiere ever with the exception of last fall's breakout hit called The Walking Dead. 
Later this year, the network will premiere season 4 of our series, Breaking Bad; season 2 of the Walking Dead; and our new original series called Hell on Wheels, which tells a story of the building of the transcontinental railroad. And we're pleased to have another 2 series of Mad Men locked in with season 5 set to air in early 2012. 
In Rainbow's other programming businesses, which primarily include our international distribution and IFC Entertainment, our film distribution business, revenue grew by 28% or $5 million to $25 million, and AOCF improved by 19% or $2 million to an AOCF loss of $7 million. Contributing to the AOCF loss were ongoing VOOM HD-related litigated expenses pertaining to this lawsuit. We are pleased with the results for the quarter. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Gregg Siebert, who will briefly cover the company's overall financials.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage r
componenttext:
Thank you, Josh. Let me start by addressing Cablevision's leverage and liquidity. At the end of the first quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $610 million. Net debt was $12.1 billion. As of March 31, the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.6x. The CSC Holdings Group and Restricted Group leverage ratio was 3.8x. 
Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we repaid CSC Holdings 7 5/8 senior notes in the amount of $326 million using cash on hand and borrowings under our revolver. Following that repayment, the outstanding balance on our revolver was $1 billion. Currently, Rainbow National Services has $1.1 billion of debt and $580 million available on its revolving credit facility. The ratio under its bond leverage desk [ph] was 2.4x as of March 31. 
We continue to make good progress on the upcoming spin-off of Rainbow or AMC Networks Inc. We recently received an IRS Private Letter Ruling confirming the spin-off of the tax-free Cablevision and the Cablevision shareholders. In addition, we are in the midst of a Form-10 review process with the SEC, and we've reached an agreement with NASDAQ to service the listing exchange for AMC. 
We continue to have discussions with our lenders regarding the financing of the transaction and currently anticipate that AMC's financing structure will consist of a $500 million revolving credit facility, $1 billion in the term loan A facility, $675 million in the term loan B facility and $750 million in unsecured notes. Proceeds from this financing will be used to refinance existing RNS debt, approximately $1.1 billion, and to fund a $1.25 billion distribution to either Cablevision or CSC Holdings to repay debt, including the drawn portion of our revolver. 
As part of the Rainbow refinancing, on April 13, RNS issued a notice of redemption to holders of $300 million of its 8 3/4% senior notes due 2012. RNS plans to use cash on hand and availability under its revolver to fund this redemption on May 13. As Jim mentioned, we continue to be on track from a timing perspective and anticipate a midyear closing for the spin. 
Turning to the company's share repurchase program. In the first quarter, we repurchased 6.7 million shares of Cablevision stock at an average price of $35.10 for a total of $234 million. From inception of the program through the end of April, we've repurchased $616 million of CVC stock at an average price of $31.74. We have $384 million of repurchase authorization remaining. 
Finally, as Jim mentioned, our quarterly dividend has been increased for the second consecutive year. The dividend increase from $0.125 to $0.15 per share per quarter will represent a meaningful increase in the yield on Cablevision stock, which of course, will be even greater after the spin-off of Rainbow. 
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: One for Tom and one for Josh. Tom, I'm just trying to get a gauge on the subaccounts. You gave the New York area essentially by breaking out Bresnan. Or with the incremental rage, do you have to sell, or do you just target share this year?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start, Doug. On the sub issue, Cablevision core system, the traditional cable system, lost about 8,400 video customers. Some of that was attributable I think to how we came into the year after the dispute we had had with News Corp. in the carriage of
componenttext: I'll start, Doug. On the sub issue, Cablevision core system, the traditional cable system, lost about 8,400 video customers. Some of that was attributable I think to how we came into the year after the dispute we had had with News Corp. in the carriage of the World Series. But we still continue to see softness in the economy, particularly in lower-income neighborhoods, New York City, Newark, Bridgeport and other parts of our systems, are not performing as well as they have in the past, and we think that's due directly to economic factors. And then that continues to be the biggest impact on us on a year-to-year basis.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Well, we had reasonably good growth in high-speed data, most of -- a lot of our high-speed data growth is coming from Triple Play customers. So I would say that the same economic forces affect data growth as they do video growth.

componenttext: This is Josh. Scatter market has been pretty good. As you may have read, as I mentioned, our ratings at AMC and WE tv were up. AMC in sales prime, high single digits; WE tv, double digits. And we really are finding that advertisers are attracted, particularly, to our original programming, which offers propriety and a distinct place for them to be, so it all seems -- that seems to be working well thus far. On the upfront it did not really kicked off. We're doing presentations. We do think that our increased original programming, particularly on AMC, is a very good opportunity for advertisers to move into things that they liked. We've seen in the past on Mad Men and Breaking Bad, and now we have more to offer.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I'm trying to figure out, Josh, is you obviously have the rating success, so that's going to be could for gaining add share, but can you gain both sort of volume and price? So if your upfront ends up, say, 10%, 11% for Cable Networks, can your pricin
componenttext: What I'm trying to figure out, Josh, is you obviously have the rating success, so that's going to be could for gaining add share, but can you gain both sort of volume and price? So if your upfront ends up, say, 10%, 11% for Cable Networks, can your pricing end up being 15%, and can you sell through the higher inventory you have with the show success? Do you get a premium for the show success that you have?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. So it's a speculative question, obviously. I think we -- in the overall front, we represent, of course, a very, very, very small piece of it. So a share increase for us would not particularly register as necessarily a notable share increase in the
componenttext: Right. So it's a speculative question, obviously. I think we -- in the overall front, we represent, of course, a very, very, very small piece of it. So a share increase for us would not particularly register as necessarily a notable share increase in the larger landscape. I think the answer is, yes, that we can increase price and certainly increase share in as much as we are a part of share, and that's not a big, big piece of the whole pie.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Two questions. First, for Tom, can you just talk about -- FiOS had a lot of aggressive promotions in the quarter. They don't seem to have had a big impact. Can you talk about responding to FiOS promotions and what you're seeing in terms of the promotional activity? And then for Gregg, given this dramatic drop in capital intensity, I wonder if you can just give us a little more insight into your plans for capital allocation after the spin-off within the cable group?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Tom. I guess, yes, FiOS is aggressive, and we are doing well relatively speaking, competitively. They have been offering very aggressive pricing for the Triple Play contrary to their expressed marketing strategy of being a premium service.
componenttext: Craig, this is Tom. I guess, yes, FiOS is aggressive, and we are doing well relatively speaking, competitively. They have been offering very aggressive pricing for the Triple Play contrary to their expressed marketing strategy of being a premium service. But we continue to respond in the marketplace with superior service and superior product offerings. We've just launched our new Boost Plus product integrated into a Triple Play. We've been the first company to put its full cable service on the iPad. The first company to be able to put all of the products on your PC, on all your TVs. So we continue to lead in terms of service and quality and product development, but it's a very competitive marketplace.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The capital intensity number was so much lower than we expected in the Cable business. And given Tom's comment about, it looks like this is sustainable, the Cable business will be generating a huge amount of cash. And I guess can we just return to the per
componenttext: The capital intensity number was so much lower than we expected in the Cable business. And given Tom's comment about, it looks like this is sustainable, the Cable business will be generating a huge amount of cash. And I guess can we just return to the perennial question of acquisitions versus share buybacks once the spin-off has happened?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I actually think you used the word "insight" in your question, so I figured that acquisitions were what was primarily on your mind. And I think, as you know, we're not going to comment on speculation regarding any specific potential acquisitio
componenttext: Sure. Well, I actually think you used the word "insight" in your question, so I figured that acquisitions were what was primarily on your mind. And I think, as you know, we're not going to comment on speculation regarding any specific potential acquisition. But I will take the opportunity to repeat the fact that we are committed to a balanced strategy for creating shareholder value. And I think that's pretty evident in what we've accomplished over the past 10 or 11 months. We've not only completed the Bresnan acquisition, but we've also repurchased over $600 million worth of stock and today announced that we've increased the dividend. I think that our leverage targets are going to remain in the range that we've discussed before, which is 4 to 5x, obviously, aiming more toward the 4.5, 4.6, range is kind of the sustainable upper end of that range, but I do need flexibility to go higher than that. And we are going to continue to look at acquisition opportunities. Our primary focus in evaluating these type of opportunities, and I'll use Bresnan as an example, is we undertook a rigorous analysis of the company and we look at the operating returns that we thought we could generate from that business and the financial structure of the transaction. And at the conclusion of that analysis, we determined that the Bresnan acquisition was going to produce higher returns for our shareholders and alternative uses of capital. Now I want to add that we've looked at other opportunities since Bresnan, and we haven't reached that same conclusion for some of the other properties that we've looked at. So I think going forward, that's the type of pretty intense acquisition analysis that you should expect from us as we look at opportunities there. And again, we intend to keep the leverage within the range we have discussed before, and we intend to continue our repurchase program.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Richard Greenfield of BTIG.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Richard Greenfield of BTIG.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One on AMC for Josh. When you look at the strong ratings growth and you had very solid revenue growth in the quarter, when do we start to see that kind of translate from a profitability standpoint? I recognize that you're investing in progr
componenttext: Two questions. One on AMC for Josh. When you look at the strong ratings growth and you had very solid revenue growth in the quarter, when do we start to see that kind of translate from a profitability standpoint? I recognize that you're investing in programming and spending a lot to promote these shows, but how long do you think is it when the upfront kicks in, in September and October? Where will we actually start to see the earnings and free cash flow benefit coming out of all the success you've had from the national networks and ratings? And then two, I know it's a minor point, but it does look like it's just a problem asset. Newsday, you don't break out anymore. Last year, you did $1 million in profit. I assume with the revenue declines, it's now losing money. Is there anything you can do beyond shutting down Newsday to limit the impact it has on kind of core Cablevision?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Josh. We -- our original program in  AMC, scripted material, began about 5 -- 4.5, 5 years ago with Mad Men, and we have been carefully adding to that. Along the way, we had Breaking Bad, as you know, and last quarter, The Walking Dead in th
componenttext: Sure. This is Josh. We -- our original program in  AMC, scripted material, began about 5 -- 4.5, 5 years ago with Mad Men, and we have been carefully adding to that. Along the way, we had Breaking Bad, as you know, and last quarter, The Walking Dead in this quarter and The Killing. Our growth during that period of time has been strong. So those shows have been working for us in combination with what is substantially still across the number of hours of the day there are movie service. So the economic productivity of it is already in evidence over the past 4 years' performance. It continues to get stronger as we add more volume and success today. In our originals, we think we have an opportunity to attract new advertisers, and we are seeing higher CPMs, so we think that trend will continue and get better, but it's already in effect.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you think the margin decline this quarter was anomaly that will work itself out timing-wise over the course of the year?
componenttext: So you think the margin decline this quarter was anomaly that will work itself out timing-wise over the course of the year?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's fairly small, and I think we're subject to some seasonality, so I don't think it's a particular trend that we'll see.
componenttext: Well, I think it's fairly small, and I think we're subject to some seasonality, so I don't think it's a particular trend that we'll see.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And with regard to Newsday, we really have 2 strategies with Newsday. One, we'd like it to be a profitable business as a stand-alone business. But it's also an integral part of our localism strategy as a cable operator. So Optimum Online customers have ac
componenttext: And with regard to Newsday, we really have 2 strategies with Newsday. One, we'd like it to be a profitable business as a stand-alone business. But it's also an integral part of our localism strategy as a cable operator. So Optimum Online customers have access to Newsday online products as part of their service. But we did successfully negotiate a new labor contract at Newsday recently. And we have taken a rate increase in Newsday, which had some negative impact on circulation -- actual home circulation during for Newsday. And so we think it's not going to be a drag from an AOCF perspective. And that as we move into the digital world that we can find ways to create new products from Newsday that will drive additional revenue. So we haven't given up on it by any means.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: I have 2 questions. First, as a follow-up to the question on data net adds, they were a little bit lower than last year's first quarter. Was that more due to lower gross adds and to higher churn? And have you seen any indication of the substitution for wireless?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't seen any indication of substitution for wireless. Our market share of data has not changed. So what you're seeing is relative to other data providers. So what you see is an overall economic impact of our ability to grow in a marketplace whe
componenttext: No, we haven't seen any indication of substitution for wireless. Our market share of data has not changed. So what you're seeing is relative to other data providers. So what you see is an overall economic impact of our ability to grow in a marketplace where there is still significantly high unemployment situations. So, no, I don't see a shift in the marketplace at all.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then secondly for Josh. On AMC and We, could you talk a little bit about the number of minutes you have available for any typical hour for advertising? I'm just wondering, as strong as the numbers have been, is the restructural improvement you make there by increasing the number of minutes?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. We think we're at the right level now at AMC and WE tv. There is the possibility, as we go forward, that we could add more inventory, but we think we're at sort of the slightly lighter end of the spectrum of cable channels with our ad load, so we d
componenttext: Right. We think we're at the right level now at AMC and WE tv. There is the possibility, as we go forward, that we could add more inventory, but we think we're at sort of the slightly lighter end of the spectrum of cable channels with our ad load, so we don't have any plans today to increase the ad load. In the future, it could be done, but we are steady state for now.

componenttext: And then, Gregg, the CapEx number was really pretty amazing, and I'm just wondering, it seems like the driver, I guess part of it is going to the Network DVR, but these numbers include Wi-Fi. Where are you in the Wi-Fi build-out? And is there a step-down in 2012?

componenttext: Right. Well, in terms of overall capital spending, customer premises equipment comes down for 2 reasons: The Network DVR, and also because we went to a downloadable security box. So we don't have a separate cable card, and each piece of equipment we buy is less expensive than we previously bought. So you have volume, you have price and you have the DVR. And those things are all a result of strategic decisions we've made to architect our system in a capitally efficient way. So what was the second part of the question?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Three if I could, actually. Quickly on the iPad app, do you have plans or the rights to extend that out of the home on to the Wi-Fi footprint for people who are video customers? Secondly, on discussing downloadable security and the like, how does that int
componenttext: Three if I could, actually. Quickly on the iPad app, do you have plans or the rights to extend that out of the home on to the Wi-Fi footprint for people who are video customers? Secondly, on discussing downloadable security and the like, how does that integrate with, say, consumer devices that have cable card slots. I mean will you be able to take advantage of if somebody bought a Samsung TV, who in a cable card system there would be no set-top box, would you need a set-top box for those going forward? And third, if you can just give us an idea how much of the video challenge you are seeing? Is it a matter of lower take rates in the home versus just a lower number of occupied homes out of the actual home passed?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the latter question is there's definitely less occupied housing per home passed than there was in prior periods. And that is a significant factor in our growth prospects for video. The first part of your question, the iPad application that we curr
componenttext: I think the latter question is there's definitely less occupied housing per home passed than there was in prior periods. And that is a significant factor in our growth prospects for video. The first part of your question, the iPad application that we currently have deployed turns your iPad into a television in the home, and it becomes an additional outlet that has the full cable TV service on it. And that is consistent with our existing in-home cable television rights that we've negotiated with everyone. To put it on a Wi-Fi network, which we could do technically with ease would require new license agreements. Some of the programmers that we're dealing with have given us TV Everywhere-type rights and go rights, which are Internet rights. And we are taking advantage of those rights and creating additional products for outside the home. With regard to the Wi-Fi, the Wi-Fi network is an Internet service, but it's controlled by us and it's for the benefit of our customers. So it actually creates another space for us to exploit and create value for our customers should we choose to. We have not sought those rights today or at least deployed them. The downloadable security question of how do we handle existing cable card slots, we still have a problem with the cable card in that it's a one-way service. And so to build a 2-way interactive service, which makes our full product functional, a set-top box is required. However, there's a whole new generation of televisions being developed, which are like the iPad in terms of their capabilities but bigger in the sense that they have a lot of processing power but they would hang on a wall. Those TVs if you think about the iPad, the iPad is actually a TV with a set-top box built into it with software. Televisions being deployed on walls, like Samsung's new smart TVs, are actually capable of having a virtual set-top box built into them in the same way that an iPad is. And so capital intensity will go down as a result of that kind of deployment once you get your network architected like we are, which is a network capable of serving every kind of device in the home.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's been so much talk about LTEs, so I'm just curious how Wi-Fi is going for you both as a retention tool and as an acquisition tool. So how are new and current customers responding? And then a question for Gregg. I think you said leverage at consolid
componenttext: There's been so much talk about LTEs, so I'm just curious how Wi-Fi is going for you both as a retention tool and as an acquisition tool. So how are new and current customers responding? And then a question for Gregg. I think you said leverage at consolidated Cablevision was 4.6x, which is at the high end of your target and an increase from last quarter, so any thoughts on your leverage or debt profile post the Rainbow spin and where you maybe levered?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll start first, if you don't mind. In terms of leverage, we're up this quarter because we repurchased additional stock and we funded it through our revolver. In the comments relating to the distribution from Rainbow, I was pretty specific about th
componenttext: Maybe I'll start first, if you don't mind. In terms of leverage, we're up this quarter because we repurchased additional stock and we funded it through our revolver. In the comments relating to the distribution from Rainbow, I was pretty specific about the fact that we would expect a portion -- the funded portion of our revolver to be repaid as a result of the Rainbow transaction. That doesn't provide additional debt capacity for us. What it does is it, just in effect, takes our revolver, pays it off and transfers a lot of that debt over to Rainbow. So I think that you can look at some of what's occurred this quarter as being positioning for the ultimate Rainbow spin-off. I do expect our leverage to come down next quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: With regard to Wi-Fi and retention and the value customers, our objective is to get our customers to use the Wi-Fi network, which they are doing in increasing amounts every day. The Wi-Fi network is faster and more capable than LTE network being built, so
componenttext: With regard to Wi-Fi and retention and the value customers, our objective is to get our customers to use the Wi-Fi network, which they are doing in increasing amounts every day. The Wi-Fi network is faster and more capable than LTE network being built, so it's really 5G, not 4G. And in terms of retention, people who do use our Wi-Fi network have lower turn rates than those who don't. So we think it's a valuable retention tool and ultimately an acquisition tool as well.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bryan Kraft of Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bryan Kraft of Evercore Partners.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, just want to see if you can clarify your comments on the economy. Are you saying that you believe the economic conditions in your footprint are more challenging now than they were say a year ago? Or are you making comparisons back to pre-credit crisi
componenttext: Tom, just want to see if you can clarify your comments on the economy. Are you saying that you believe the economic conditions in your footprint are more challenging now than they were say a year ago? Or are you making comparisons back to pre-credit crisis conditions? And then I just have one other question. Were there integration costs in the quarter related to Bresnan? And how do you see kind of upside to margins later in the year playing out as Bresnan becomes more fully integrated?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of the economy, housing occupation -- occupied housing as a percentage of all housing is still declining. So you have the effects of the economy bringing themselves out in people actually leaving their homes, leaving their apartment, moving
componenttext: Well, in terms of the economy, housing occupation -- occupied housing as a percentage of all housing is still declining. So you have the effects of the economy bringing themselves out in people actually leaving their homes, leaving their apartment, moving in with each other, and that has [indiscernible] and that is worse year-over-year. I think, ultimately, it stabilizes, but there are still a significant number of people who are unemployed and running out of money. In terms of margins, I can't really speculate on the impact of Bresnan on margins. It's about 10% of our business, and we are going to ramp that business up this year. And so I don't think you'll see a significant material impact as a result of that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bryan, one thing you'll see in the first quarter is we did have approximately $8 million worth of spin-offs associated with the AMC spend. And so that's one item that is not going to be a repeat item after the spin takes place.
componenttext: Bryan, one thing you'll see in the first quarter is we did have approximately $8 million worth of spin-offs associated with the AMC spend. And so that's one item that is not going to be a repeat item after the spin takes place.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Were there any explicit integration costs, real integration costs in the quarter related to Bresnan that you can call out? Or was it more just kind of normal course operations with a little more activity because of the integration?

componenttext: I'll call it normal course activities.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your final question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Starting with Josh. The Form-10 has some interesting discussions about your programming strategy and you want to own more of your own content. And I believe you that -- I believe, I could be wrong, I think Walking Dead was your first sort of Rainbow-produ
componenttext: Starting with Josh. The Form-10 has some interesting discussions about your programming strategy and you want to own more of your own content. And I believe you that -- I believe, I could be wrong, I think Walking Dead was your first sort of Rainbow-produced or AMC-produced piece of content, and obviously, Mad Men and others, you licensed. Just wondering if you changed the mix over time going forward and what that might mean going back to sort of the programming investment margin question from earlier today? And then for Tom, I was wondering if there's anything you'd point out that would lead to revenue growth accelerating from cable. If you strip out, Bresnan, I think in the release you said it was 2% this quarter. It sounds like it's the economy really holding back units and maybe ARPU as well. Just wondering if you think there's anything else we should be focused on in terms of reaccelerating the top line?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Josh. We do think related to the Form-10 that the more we can own content and control content, the better off we are if we can do it economically. It gives us the ability if we have a greater ownership position, and it actually is a spectrum quest
componenttext: This is Josh. We do think related to the Form-10 that the more we can own content and control content, the better off we are if we can do it economically. It gives us the ability if we have a greater ownership position, and it actually is a spectrum question, it's not binary, you don't either own or license it, there are sort of steps in between, but if we can own increasingly in increments, then we get the benefit of being able to put it on different platforms, being the beneficiary of its exploitation and subsequent ancillary markets, being able to distribute it internationally. We have to date been able to on the nonfiction side, which is more for WE tv and IFC, take ownership positions that are more complete. It's a lower price tag to do reality TV or nonfiction, so it's less risky. And so more of the content on that site is owned. On AMC, where we're dealing with higher price tags for scripted, you're quite right that we have one series where we have a significant near-complete ownership position, and that's The Walking Dead. We did that because we thought that the nature of the material, which is typically referred to as genre, horror, was less risky than some of the other material that we've traded in, and it was a good bet. And it seems to be borne out because it was successful, and we will get the benefits that I described a moment ago. As we go forward, we would just evaluate each proposition and determine whether the risk profile of a series or a show seems to make sense and whether the economics makes sense. So I don't think you'll see any one particular pattern emerging, it will be opportunistic and it will be case-by-case.  Where we can own more, if we think it's sensible, we will.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of revenue drivers, this product that we just launched, Boost Plus, the 50-megabit service, which integrates additional functionality like Optimum Link inside that service is a $15 a month product. So it essentially rides on top of our e
componenttext: And then in terms of revenue drivers, this product that we just launched, Boost Plus, the 50-megabit service, which integrates additional functionality like Optimum Link inside that service is a $15 a month product. So it essentially rides on top of our existing data business. It's a new data tier, and we've integrated it into our acquisition strategy. So that will produce incremental revenue per customer going forward and creates an upgrade opportunity to our existing subscriber base to increase revenue per sub as well. We took a very light rate increase this year as we came into the year. Because of the situation that we had in the fourth quarter, we thought that in the long run we'd be wiser to have a more moderate rate increase this year, so we had that as well. And we sort of complemented or offset that to some extent going forward with our new revenue drivers as a result of the Boost Plus strategy.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call for Cablevision. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Ms. Pat Armstrong, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team including Jim Dolan, our President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Greg
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team including Jim Dolan, our President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Don Coleman, Senior Vice President, Financial Planning and Control. Following a discussion of the company's second quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. 
Please take note of the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. 
Let me point out that on Page 5 of today's earnings release, we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of our adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF, to operating income. I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the second quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 9% to $1.69 billion and AOCF increased 2.3% to $574 million. These results reflect the addition of Bresnan as well as a one-time favorable program cost adjus
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the second quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 9% to $1.69 billion and AOCF increased 2.3% to $574 million. These results reflect the addition of Bresnan as well as a one-time favorable program cost adjustment that occurred in the second quarter of 2010. Without these items, revenue growth would have been 1.5% and AOCF growth would have been essentially flat for the quarter. These results also exclude AMC Networks, which was successfully spun off in June. 
For the first six months of 2011, Cablevision generated $354 million of free cash flow, a 31% increase over the prior year on a pro forma basis. Even without the contribution from Bresnan, free cash flow would have increased by 21%. The company repurchased more than 4 million shares in the second quarter. In addition, the Board of Directors has once again approved a $0.15 dividend payable in September. With the successful completion of our second spin off in 2 years, I am optimistic about what lies ahead for the new Cablevision. 
While weakened economy and the competitive pressures impact our subscriber metrics this quarter, I'm confident that our superior architecture and network combined with our new product innovations will ensure that we continue to deliver better products and greater value for our customers. We have always been focused on a strategy that includes capitalizing on our investments in our Cable business and exceeding our customer's expectations on every level. And as Cablevision CEO, I can assure you that the focus has never been stronger than it is now. I would now like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, Jim. Telecommunications revenue for the quarter was $1.6 billion, an increase of 9.8% over the prior year period. Excluding the impact of the recently acquired Bresnan properties, total revenue growth was 1.7% year-over-year. In th
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, Jim. Telecommunications revenue for the quarter was $1.6 billion, an increase of 9.8% over the prior year period. Excluding the impact of the recently acquired Bresnan properties, total revenue growth was 1.7% year-over-year. 
In the second quarter, our total company results included an increase of 5,000 high-speed data customers, 27,000 new voice lines and a video loss of 23,000. In the Eastern Cablevision operations, average revenue per sub, or RPS, was $154.86, up 1.7% sequentially and up 3.8% over the prior year period. Our rate increase at the end of last year was smaller than normal due to the earlier retransmission issue yet RPS has grown steadily. And we are exceeding the marketplace with a higher price package to our new ultimate Triple Play priced $10 higher than Triple Play. Introduced in May the Ultimate Triple Play already represents over 50% of our new acquisition Triple Play customers. These customers are voluntarily agreed to higher rates in response to the enhanced services offered in the Ultimate Triple Play package. 
In the Eastern Cablevision footprint, our telco competition remains active and the economy has seen little improvement. While the second quarter is traditionally a stronger growth quarter for us, these 2 factors made our growth more challenging. And this trend has continued into the third quarter. 
However, our optimum business service has grown steadily. Optimum Lightpath revenue was $77 million in the quarter, which was an increase of 9% versus the prior year period. Lightpath now provides service to over 4,700 buildings, an increase of 17% over the prior year.  
Second quarter AOCF for Telecommunications segment was $625 million, representing an increase of 1.8% over the prior year. And last year's second quarter for the Cable company there was a nonrecurring favorable adjustment of $23 million. Excluding that impact as well as the Bresnan impact, AOCF would've been flat year-over-year. 
Operating expenses at Cable remained in check in the quarter, increasing only 2.8% on a pro forma basis. Optimum Lightpath AOCF grew by 17% in the quarter to $32.7 million. Margins continue to rise at Lightpath and in the second quarter, Lightpath AOCF margin was 42.4%. 
Bresnan properties now branded, Optimum, have been under our ownership for about 6 months. Already these properties have a Triple Play selling rate of roughly 50% compared with 20% at the time of our acquisition. 
Total Cable advertising revenue increased 22% over the prior year period without the inclusion of the Bresnan properties was up 13% on a same-store basis. This marks the seventh consecutive quarter of double-digit add sales growth. While traditional add sales are strong, we are complementing this revenue through the use of our advanced advertising products. 
As an example, Optimum Select, which is available across the entire core footprint launched the new RFI product in the second quarter where advertisers can now fulfill customer requests for coupons for, et cetera through e-mail response. E-mail is attractive not only to our customers but it's very important to advertisers who can save on posters and shipping costs and still reach customers on a timely basis. We've now implemented hundreds of RFI campaigns for various advertisers, which generate more highly qualified leads. Additionally, we'd run a large volume of 30-second, adds that lead to advertisers long-form content in 10 to 20 minutes of engagement by our subscribers. Each of these are examples of how we continue to enhance our advanced advertising offerings, which in turn drive incremental advertising revenue for us. 
Overall, in order to continue to drive growth and to compete aggressively, we're keenly focused on adding more and more value to the products and services our customers enjoy today. We're doing this  through enhancement of existing products and services as well as through the addition of new and unique products. 
Recently, we rolled out Network DVR Plus in New York City and Connecticut and plan to launch it in Nassau County this fall and County early next year. This is a much more than the whole house DVR solution. Our service will, our customers to choose how much storage they would like and take advantage of multiple simultaneous playbacks. We've launched the iPad app where customers can view essentially all of our channels within streamline navigation on an iPad. Earlier today, we've launched the same application for iPhones and iPod Touches and at the same time added a remote control capability for all these devices on all TVs in the home. We're currently drilling in front of 50,000 customers, our enhanced set-top user interface, which includes more sophisticated search products, one of which is Movie Explorer, our own recognition engine, allowing s to dramatically increase the number of movie titles we can offer on Video-on-Demand. We've increased WiFi speeds to 50 megabits downstream and 4 megabits upstream. And we've introduced, as I said earlier, the Ultimate Triple Play, which includes the new faster, higher speeds service plus and a wireless router. And coming soon, we are planning to reduce the same functionality, which we have deployed on the iPad and Apple products on Androids, smartphones and tablets as well as PCs and Macs. All of these devices will be serviced by our integrated whole house products leading us the clear competitive leader in the telecommunications marketplace. 
As a result of these ongoing new product efforts, Cable capital spending in the quarter increased appreciably from the previous quarter as we invested in Boost Plus, iPad app development and RS-DVR. 
Total Cable capital for the quarter was $175 million or 11.6% of Cable revenue. On a year-to-date basis, total Cable capital spending was $282 million or 9.4% of revenue. If you look at the Eastern Cablevision operations on a standalone basis, capital efficiency for the first half of 2011 was 9.0% compared with the prior year period, capital efficiency of 10.8%. I'd now like to turn this call over to Gregg Seibert for a financial review.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. As I'm sure you're all aware, we successfully completed the spinoff of AMC Networks on June 30. On the date of the distribution, we effectively provided our shareholders with a $9 per share tax-free dividend. As it was demonstrated providi
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. As I'm sure you're all aware, we successfully completed the spinoff of AMC Networks on June 30. On the date of the distribution, we effectively provided our shareholders with a $9 per share tax-free dividend. As it was demonstrated providing strong shareholder returns is fundamental for the company strategy. 
Now that we've completed the spin, I thought I'd take a moment to mention that the results of AMC Networks, including costs associated with the spends is legal and professional fees are now reported as discontinued operations. Also reflected in discontinued operations are the management fees, which have previously been charged by Cablevision to AMC Networks. I should caution that AMC's results of operations reported on a standalone basis will differ from the results presented in the Cablevision earnings release and 10-Q with certain reclassifications and adjustments made for the purposes of Discontinued Operations reporting. 
Turning to leverage and liquidity. At the end of the second quarter, the company's consolidated cash position is $357 million. Net debt was $9.9 billion and on June 30, we have $1.35 billion undrawn under the $1.41 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings. The drawn portion is primarily backstops for letters of credit. 
As of June 30, the company's consolidated leverage ratio is 4.4x and the CSC Holdings Restricted Group leverage was 3.1x. In April, the CSC Holdings repaid in full it's maturing $326 million, 7 5/8% senior notes and with revolver borrowings and cash on hand. And as a reminder, we utilized our revolver to execute our share repurchases in the first half of this year. As a result of the spin off and refinancing of AMC Networks, AMC distributed to Cablevision $1.25 billion, all of which was used to pay down borrower under the CSC Holdings revolver. 
At June 30, Bresnan net debt was approximately $1 billion with $75 million undrawn and available on its revolving credit facility. The leverage for the quarter was 7.2x. There were number of expenses incurred in the first half, including the wind down of our contract with a third-party voice provisioning company, the ramp up of our sales and marketing efforts and the Optimum rebranding, which impacted AOCF. We expect the Bresnan operating margins and leverage ratio to improve in upcoming quarters and I remain excited about Bresnan's prospects. 
Turning to Cablevision share repurchase program. In the second quarter, we repurchased approximately 4.2 million shares of Cablevision stock, totaling $143.9 million. From inception of the program from the end of June, we have repurchased 21.7 million shares totaling $695 million. We have $305 million of repurchase authorization available under our existing program and we expect to continue to be opportunistic in our approach to share repurchases. Since the beginning of the repurchase program in June of 2010, our total outstanding class A shares have decreased from $251 million to $231 million shrinking the total class A share base by approximately 8%. 
Free cash flow for the quarter was $122 million. It compares with the pro forma first quarter free cash flow of $232 million. This quarterly variance was driven largely by increased capital spending of $83 million in the quarter as we invested in new product initiatives. Free cash flow per share for the first 6 months of 2011 was $1.23, a 38% increase compared with pro forma free cash flow of $0.89 per share in the prior year period. 
I also want to take an opportunity to update our investors on our NOL position. At June 30, the NOL of Cablevision was $1.6 billion, down from the prior quarter amount of $1.9 billion, primarily reflecting the amount of the NOL with AMC and the spin off. We've taken advantage of the bonus depreciation provisions in 2010 and 2011 and intend to do so again and although and this is given us about 14 or 15 months of additional NOL cover. We currently estimate that we will not fully use the NOL until sometime in 2013. Finally, diluted earnings per share was $0.31 for the quarter, up from $0.20 in the prior year period. Excluding income from discontinued operations, EPS was $0.24 in the second quarter versus $0.07 in the prior year period. Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from the line of Craig Moffett with Bernstein.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: A question for Tom. Tom, can you talk about your expectations for how you make the Cable business grow? I know you've talked in the past about your optimism for continued penetration of additional services. Can you just update us on your thinking and wher
componenttext: A question for Tom. Tom, can you talk about your expectations for how you make the Cable business grow? I know you've talked in the past about your optimism for continued penetration of additional services. Can you just update us on your thinking and where are the growth opportunities in this business and kind of what we can expect going forward?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think obviously we're in a challenging economic times and a highly competitive world. But I'm still very optimistic about the business itself and its growth prospects in the  long term. We continue to have a big opportunity to grow that business u
componenttext: Well, I think obviously we're in a challenging economic times and a highly competitive world. But I'm still very optimistic about the business itself and its growth prospects in the  long term. We continue to have a big opportunity to grow that business universe and the actual opportunity are maybe bigger in terms of penetration opportunity than there actually is in the Video business and in the Residential Voice business because almost all businesses I think will continue to have a wireline voice product to a foreseeable future. So there is a still a tremendous opportunity in the Small Business marketplace, there's still a big opportunity where Lightpath competes to grow those businesses. There's big opportunity to grow the Advertising business going forward and to take more share out of the market. I think you continue to see a shift out of traditional media. Television continues to work quite well and continues to attract dollars. And the interactive platform we've built, I think it allow us to actually not just maintain our share this business but shift the share in the future. And I still think in the long run, the Residential business is an opportunity for us with our superior products, continue to grow penetration. We are at very high penetrations in our marketplace. There's very little housing growth going on right now and there's actually a high vacancy rate. All of that hurts the Residential business at the moment, but for the long run, I expect that we will have a more normal economy in the future and that residential growth will take advantage of that.

componenttext: We don't have a current business plan to exploit that as a new revenue opportunity. But obviously, digital world and the digital products that we provide are capable of pretty much any communications product that you can conceive of in the home and in the business. So to the extent there's an opportunity there, we can take advantage of it.

componenttext: I guess sort of following up little bit, I look at the state of competition right now, Tom, any more details that you could give us would be helpful with regards to the level of promotional intensity as you move from 2Q to 3Q. A lot of your peers have talked about increasing competitive intensity and also a number of your peers talked about real softness even in mid-May and any sort of comments about how the business is trend lining would be a helpful?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we're subject to the same national forces that the industry is. We do have a big wireline competitive overlap with Verizon. They have been very aggressive through the second quarter with promotional offers. Satellite in our marketplace
componenttext: Well, I think that we're subject to the same national forces that the industry is. We do have a big wireline competitive overlap with Verizon. They have been very aggressive through the second quarter with promotional offers. Satellite in our marketplace continues to shrink in terms of market share and are less impactful directly to us than maybe the rest of the industry and we haven't seen any uptick in economic activity in the housing market, which does impact our business.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Would you say that the files, the competition has become irrational or still manageable? Or are you optimistic that you can actually sort of start to improve share against FiOS?
componenttext: Would you say that the files, the competition has become irrational or still manageable? Or are you optimistic that you can actually sort of start to improve share against FiOS?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We hope to increase share against FiOS. I mean we continue to interestingly maintain our market share and data. We continue to grow our Voice business. And is since our FiOS competition actually began, we've increased our total customer relationship subsc
componenttext: We hope to increase share against FiOS. I mean we continue to interestingly maintain our market share and data. We continue to grow our Voice business. And is since our FiOS competition actually began, we've increased our total customer relationship subscribers by more than 10%. And yes, we have lost several points of video penetration but it is a marketplace where we can continue to provide superior products, superior customer service and compete aggressively and continue to grow our RPS by adding new value products into our sales mix and using our selling techniques to drive our customers toward those products. So yes, it's been very competitive. Looking at their pricing and what  they have to do to grow market share, is it irrational? I think they lose free cash flow on every customer they connect. If that's rational, it is irrational.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, you guys have been ahead of your peers in terms of new products, going back to WiFi and Network DVR. You've tended to not try to charge incrementally for most of these parts. And I'm wondering as you look at the ARPU trends, FiOS doing what it's doin
componenttext: Tom, you guys have been ahead of your peers in terms of new products, going back to WiFi and Network DVR. You've tended to not try to charge incrementally for most of these parts. And I'm wondering as you look at the ARPU trends, FiOS doing what it's doing, if your thinking that there might be opportunities to sort of monetize some of the stuff a little bit more aggressively as you look at over the next 6 to 12 months, PC and TV relay, all the things you guys have been over the last kind of 2 years?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there are multiple ways of monetizing what we're doing to our network. Ultimately, it's a question of creating value for your customers that sometimes gives you pricing power and your overall mix. And sometimes, there are opportunities to sell your
componenttext: Well, there are multiple ways of monetizing what we're doing to our network. Ultimately, it's a question of creating value for your customers that sometimes gives you pricing power and your overall mix. And sometimes, there are opportunities to sell your way into the marketplace with new products to drive incremental ARPU each transaction. And we choose different methodologies to drive value. And the point I was trying to make a little earlier in my presentation that sequentially, our RPS has grown pretty nicely. And that's a result of selling in any transactional product at a high penetration rate. On the other hand, WiFi, we don't charge for. And the reason we don't is we think we need to build value overtime by creating utilization of that product. It's not a product that has immediate economic observable value to a customer until they utilize product. So as that becomes more utilized because there's pricing power on our overall subscriber relationship, so we think there is a way to monetize Network DVR and not only an opportunity for monetization because it offers new services and new functionality that aren't offered by traditional DVR. But it's a less expensive capital project as well in the subscriber basis, which either gives us the opportunity to charge the same rates as our competitors at lower costs. And in terms of product differentiation, you can argue it gives us a higher revenue per subscriber opportunity as well. So it depends on the product, how it's rolled out and how it's perceived in the mind of the consumer when this initially launched.

componenttext: I just have a question on the AOCF in the quarter because I want to make sure I'm not missing something. componenttext: On the AMC management fees, they're no longer absorbing the $32 million worth of an overhead allocation that we had allocated to them. Of that, roughly half has been reduced on our end. And in conjunction with that, we also suffered some -- we also suffered some severance cost as we reduced overhead. And so I think that's probably the effect that you are seeing.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: The Verizon footprint is throughout our service area, which includes New Jersey, Westchester, New York City and Long Island. And their tactics are the same throughout the footprint and they have been aggressive in their offer strategy in the second quarte
componenttext: The Verizon footprint is throughout our service area, which includes New Jersey, Westchester, New York City and Long Island. And their tactics are the same throughout the footprint and they have been aggressive in their offer strategy in the second quarter and in the first quarter and that's throughout our footprint. The economic impact on our customers in lower income neighborhoods is more pronounced. And we see less gross adds in low-income areas and that's the result of economics and vacancies. It's also true to a lesser extent in the higher income areas where we're more competitive as well. So there's not economic pain in competitive areas and there's aggressive competition in competitive areas.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. First of all, on capital returns and capital structure in general, should I take it that you're still targeting 4 to 4.5x net debt to EBITDA as the right leverage level for the business? And secondly, you mentioned that you are expecting
componenttext: Two, if I could. First of all, on capital returns and capital structure in general, should I take it that you're still targeting 4 to 4.5x net debt to EBITDA as the right leverage level for the business? And secondly, you mentioned that you are expecting the NOL to run into 2013 at this point. Given the universal impacts of stimulus, should we expect to see in any time thereafter cash tax that you actually run both book taxes or in the line going forward?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the first question in terms of leverage ratio and leverage targets. We're 4.4x now on a net basis. That's a very comfortable level for us and I would say that the range we continue to look at is a 4 to 4.5x. I don't rule out the possibil
componenttext: Let me start with the first question in terms of leverage ratio and leverage targets. We're 4.4x now on a net basis. That's a very comfortable level for us and I would say that the range we continue to look at is a 4 to 4.5x. I don't rule out the possibility of going higher under extraordinary circumstances but I don't see those circumstances on the horizon. So we're comfortable with where the leverage is now and our target range. In terms of the NOL, I don't have -- I have a, here today but my sense is that you should not see periods where cash taxes run above the taxes.

componenttext: If you're able to raise some deals now that the acquisition prices have presumably gotten a little sane or posted inside with the free fall in the financial markets, would you be inclined to do that? I mean obviously if your stock at this level, that's the most compelling, application, your balance sheet flexibility, generically. And then secondly, if I might, could you talk about any implications EPON of long-term over Verizon? Or is that pretty relevant given the capacity both Verizon now and you with your networks?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the acquisition topic first. I think as anybody on this call knows, we've been associated with every potential acquisition in the cable industry over the last 9 months. I've seen research reports before having us buying 3 or 4 different targ
componenttext: Let me answer the acquisition topic first. I think as anybody on this call knows, we've been associated with every potential acquisition in the cable industry over the last 9 months. I've seen research reports before having us buying 3 or 4 different targets and I think the reality is it very much what we stated from the time that we've made of the Bresnan acquisition. We start with an operating plan. We determine what we think we can do with the asset. We look at the returns from those types of acquisitions and we compare them to opportunities such as repurchasing our own stock. And I think again, Bresnan for us was almost a unique situation. It have a combination of an operating attributes and financial attributes, which made it especially attractive. And we will continue to believe looking at acquisition opportunities going forward but I don't see anything on the immediate horizon in that regard. And I'd also point out that given the disruption in the markets at this point in time, it will be very difficult to allow a ring fence transaction today and use nonrecourse debt to deal with the high yield markets locked up, quite a bit over the last few months. And part of the issue with the auction process as we see it is that we're oftentimes asked to make a financial commitment as in the case of Bresnan, 6 months before actually doing the financing. And I think in today's market, there's a tremendous amount of markets risk in the flex terms on any type of a commitment from our friends in the banking community would be dramatically wider. And so I think that the ability to finance on a ring fence basis at this point in time is quite reduced. So we'll see where the acquisition market goes but at this point in time as Jim and Tom have pointed out, we're focused on our core operations and Bresnan.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: On your BPON, GPON question, most of the plan that Verizon built on our footprint is BPON, which is a less capable network than what they've been building in more recent times. Regardless of which network they have, our network is able to provide superior
componenttext: On your BPON, GPON question, most of the plan that Verizon built on our footprint is BPON, which is a less capable network than what they've been building in more recent times. Regardless of which network they have, our network is able to provide superior products and continue to lead and innovate in terms of data speed, in-home wireless products and IP products that you see us launching today on the various iPhone, iTouches and iPads and the ability to integrate all of these products seamlessly to the benefit of the consumer at low cost. I think ultimately, we have a superior architecture not only because it can do everything that the finest network can do but can do less expensively.

componenttext: A few. Could you start with, Bresnan, you said depressed EBITDA in the quarter and the first half. How big was that in each of those?
