componenttext: I just had a question regarding the sequential change in EBITDA. I thought last quarter, there were a number of one-time items related to the Bresnan integration and some other sort of one-time costs. I thought we're going to. So can you just spend a little bit of time daisy-chaining this through sort of the 2Q to 3Q expenses so we can try and do better job I guess going forward?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement at Bresnan with the third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-h
componenttext: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement at Bresnan with the third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-house this past quarter. Now that resulted in a margin improvement at Bresnan where we picked up, let's call it roughly 2.7%, 2.8% in the Bresnan margin. And in terms of Cablevision, I don't recall any sort of one-time startup costs or the other issues that went away this quarter. As I mentioned in my commentary, certainly, we had higher programming costs and I can't get in obviously into detail of the individual contracts with you can imagine which ones are flowing through this year. As a result of various retransmission, consent processes or negotiations. We had some increases in network management costs, increases in sales and telemarketing cost and increases in our overall product marketing costs. That's what resulted in the compression of margins this quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask 1 follow-up here? I guess because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, they're sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going to x growth. Do you think that's a f
componenttext: Can I just ask 1 follow-up here? I guess because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, they're sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going to x growth. Do you think that's a fair characterization that we've seen peak EBITDA do think that's a mischaracterization?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there are definitely cyclical pressure on the business as there are a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. and in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued oppo
componenttext: I think there are definitely cyclical pressure on the business as there are a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. and in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued opportunity to sell a Triple Play package to residential customers who don't buy today. There's still a considerable amount of satellite penetration in our footprint which we think is an inferior product at its core. And ultimately, gives us a path to additional residential growth. The business opportunity for continued penetration of telecommunication services in the business environment continues. Even that area is challenged, although it is growing rapidly in terms of share, you still have a lot of pressure in the business universe in terms of growth there as well because of the cyclical situation. And you have the opportunity to continue to shift advertising share on to the cable platform and interactive platform. So I think all of this growth drivers still exist in the business and you have a situation currently where you have a pretty slow housing growth -- virtually no housing growth, and actual reduction in household formation. People are moving in with each other. So it's a cyclically challenging time. But the ultimate drivers I think is still in the business.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011

As they get more aggressive as they talked about doing in the fourth quarter, do you expect sort of a typical seasonal rebound here or should we temper that a little bit?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011

componenttext: I don't want to give you a production on the fourth quarter. We're talking about the third quarter today. But in terms of Verizon's behavior, they were challenged in the third quarter. They were also very aggressive in the second quarter, which I think was done in anticipation of the third quarter situation. So when you look at it over the whole year, their performance is fairly consistent with prior years.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, I guess. For Tom, you said you instituted a smaller rate increase than planned to enhance consumer value I think was sort of the point. Are you essentially pricing to the lowest common denominator in your footprint, given the econom
componenttext: A couple of questions, I guess. For Tom, you said you instituted a smaller rate increase than planned to enhance consumer value I think was sort of the point. Are you essentially pricing to the lowest common denominator in your footprint, given the economic cyclicality? Any thoughts to whether you hope to increase revenue momentum by segmenting more aggressively?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confr
componenttext: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confrontational situation where the World Series was taking off our Cable system. And as that unfolded and we lost customers, we thought that we should take a less aggressive stance towards a normalized rate increase than we had in the past. And so, we took a smaller rate increase. We then implemented of Boost Plus strategy where we began to sell in customers at a higher rate, but we were doing that transactionally. And that continues in half of our Triple Play sell-in now is this new Boost product which has a $10 higher revenue component in it than the previous Triple Play promotional product. So we're moving the subscriber base, but moving it transactionally.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, go back to a conversation you and I had a while back about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases, as you've talked through that, is there any way that you
componenttext: Tom, go back to a conversation you and I had a while back about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases, as you've talked through that, is there any way that you think you can reposition the business so that you're not so beholden to the relentless price increases from your video suppliers?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost, and it gets -- it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways. It's
componenttext: Well as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost, and it gets -- it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways. It's in the retrans fee itself. It's also in the launch of additional channels and the rates associated with them. And after our last fight with Fox over the retransmission consent during the World Series last year, Congress got involved, and then the FCC actually put out a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. And that process is going on. So we are seeking regulatory relief, regulatory changes that would make that less impactful to our business. And we continue to pursue that.

componenttext: Obviously, programmers just sell their content the way they do and it is a great distribution model, and it's very attractive for content companies to sell to 100 million homes and the cable business has been built on that and it's a great business model. My comments were, in terms of Netflix and in terms of it being a pay service and being on television, but I don't expect that the business model that we currently have is about to collapse.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The answer to your second question is no, it is lumpy and we had some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run. And they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marketing or s
componenttext: The answer to your second question is no, it is lumpy and we had some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run. And they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marketing or some new uptick that is permanent. With regard to programming, yes, it is an issue, and it is an expensive part of our businesses. It is the single biggest cost item we have. And the fact that retransmission consent became necessary from the eyes of broadcasters, particularly after the '08 recession, has been flowing through our business. And there was a large step up. I think that the overall rate of programming going forward will moderate to some extent naturally, but right now, we're absorbing the collapse of the broadcast industry business model.

componenttext: A couple if I could. First of all, in terms of buyback slowing in the quarter versus prior quarters of this is our run rate we should be looking at or was that really driven by desire to keep leveraged, a certain level given the hurricane influence EBITDA? Secondly, you got the swap expiring next year. You have thoughts on how you plan to handle that, renewed let's look at what the impact of that could be? And third, Tom it's interesting understand correctly that you think that occupied homes might actually be declining in your footprint?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out in my comments that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history year over a 5 quarter period, w
componenttext: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out in my comments that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history year over a 5 quarter period, we've retired roughly 10% of our Class A share. So the way I've been looking at the program, and I think we've been thinking about it, has been trying to just over time, make a significant reduction in the number of outstanding shares. And so I don't it's all so hard to look at last quarter or any particular quarter, and declare it be more or less than prior quarters because while the absolute dollars changed a lot, there have been the AMC spend is taking place. And so the dollars that we had to allocate to repurchase in the past reflected the AMC, AOCF also. The constraint that we face right now is our leverage. We're approximately 4.5x after backing out the impact of Hurricane Irene. And even though that number is in the upper end of our normal target range, we're comfortable at that leverage level. We have $200 million remaining of repurchase authorization from our board, and we expect to continue to be opportunistic in looking at repurchases. But one thing that we're not at this point in time prepared to do, is to ramp up our leverage to buy back additional stock. We are at the upper end of that range, and I think we've been pretty consistent about wanting to stay in that type of a leverage range. Oh, on the swap side, yes, we have a substantial portion of our interest rate swaps coming off around June 30 of next year. The impact of that is roughly $50 million a year at current interest rates. We haven't made any determination at this point in time how much of that we're going to continue to allow to flow if any or have maybe we made any decision that we're going to go out and reswap. We continuously look at our capital structure. We've been very focused on extending maturities. And as we get closer to the swaps coming off, we'll certainly make decisions as to where we want to be.

componenttext: Yes, well, if you look year-over-year, we've taken that sell in rate of the Triple Play and the Bresnan property from 19% to 50%. And that's without the completion yet of the ring and without the full deployment of all the video product that we want to be fully HD-competitive with satellite. So we think that there's significant upside opportunity in those markets. That's why we purchased those assets. We think that when our full deployment is completed, that we'll have a superior product to all of our competitors in that footprint. And that we'll be able to continue growth and get we don't have to make equal Eastern market share to make that thing an attractive investment. But we're rapidly moving up the curve.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could please update on your thinking for wireless strategy given that you've got some increasing exposure to iPad apps and what have you?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could please update on your thinking for wireless strategy given that you've got some increasing exposure to iPad apps and what have you?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've been building out of WiFi network, and we've had continuous to subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we continue to deploy products that we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full cabl
componenttext: We've been building out of WiFi network, and we've had continuous to subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we continue to deploy products that we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full cable television service in the home. And we're deploying a new boost product with higher speed broadband, which includes a more sophisticated wireless router as part of that package. 70% of our customer base that subscribes to high-speed data which is 92% of our video base, has a wireless router in their home. So we think WiFi is a major strategic part of our business. We think that we can continue to take advantage of that. We think our video product today as a result of WiFi, is a superior product to our competitors, all of our competitors. And we think that our data service is enhanced by the WiFi outside the home. And we continue to try to build value for our customers and take market share. Our broadband share remains that about 75% and notwithstanding the competition in this marketplace. And this is a more aggressive market, but we have a better broadband product than our competitors, and part about as our WiFi strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Gregg
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Donna Coleman, Senior Vice President, Financial Planning and Control.  Following a discussion of the company's third quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please take note of the following: Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results, and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. And let me point out that on Page 5 of today's earnings release, we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF, to operating income.
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the third quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 8% to $1.67 billion while AOCF was essentially flat at $539 million when compared to the prior-year period. These results were impacted by Hurricane Irene, as
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the third quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 8% to $1.67 billion while AOCF was essentially flat at $539 million when compared to the prior-year period. These results were impacted by Hurricane Irene, as well as the addition of the Bresnan properties. Without these 2 items, revenue growth would've been essentially flat and AOCF would've decreased 4% for the quarter. Cablevision generated $440 million in free cash flow from continuing operations over the last 9 months, a 5% improvement over 2010. In addition, the company repurchased more than 5 million shares in the third quarter, and the Board of Directors has approved a quarterly dividend of $0.15 per share, payable in December.
The impact of Hurricane Irene resulted in an extended loss of electricity in a significant part of our footprint in the New York metropolitan area. Cablevision met this challenge well, responding to customers' needs and restoring service quickly. Tom is going to talk, in more detail, about the business and also highlight some positive underlying trends in our performance. These include certain improved subscriber metrics, during a quarter that has historically been seasonally weak for Cablevision, and continued growth at Optimum Lightpath. Not all of our results in the quarter are where we want them. By many measures, we have built the most successful Cable Television company in the nation, and have set nearly every industry benchmark for sales, customer retention, penetration, and financial performance. Continuing to build upon this historical performance has become more challenging in a highly competitive environment which is compounded by economic pressures, including a significant decline in housing activity. However, we are addressing the challenge and, in many ways, have been preparing for it for several years. We have taken pioneering steps to develop products and enhance our services for our customers without straining their wallets. We have sought and identified new markets that offer attractive growth opportunities to which we allocate a portion of our investable capital. Both Optimum Business and Bresnan exemplify this. And, as importantly, we have aggressively addressed the financial and capital structure of Cablevision to optimize long-term shareholder returns through the refinancing of our balance sheet, the spin off of MSG and AMC, and the allocation of our investable capital to our quarterly dividend, our stock buyback plan, and highly strategic acquisitions. That said, our primary focus is the continued improvement of our product offerings, the quality of our services, and the provision of the most attractive price value proposition in the market for our customers.  Historically, Cablevision has confronted challenges in a constantly involving business over multiple business cycles. We are highly confident that the same spirit of service, innovation, and execution will guide us as we move forward. 
We'll now like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. For the third quarter, Telecom revenue grew by 9% versus the prior year quarter, and AOCF was essentially flat. We suffered hurricane damage in the third quarter, which cost us $16 million. Excluding both the impact of Br
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. For the third quarter, Telecom revenue grew by 9% versus the prior year quarter, and AOCF was essentially flat. We suffered hurricane damage in the third quarter, which cost us $16 million. Excluding both the impact of Bresnan and the hurricane, Telecom AOCF declined by 3.9% in the third quarter over the prior year.
In addition to lack of housing growth, there are several other factors that have impacted the quarter-over-quarter revenue growth for the fiscal year. We had an unusual fourth quarter sub loss last year due to a programming dispute, which led us to take a smaller rate increase in plan to stabilize the customer base over the long term. And Verizon unilaterally reduced voice interconnection fees, which were in the revenue line, and which we are litigating. While our third quarter is seasonally our weakest quarter, we were aided by the launch of new services on the iPod Touch and iPhone, which were integrated into our promotions. In addition, one of our competitors had a strike which hurt their performance. Basic video, data, and voice lines all had net changes, which were an improvement not only of last year's third quarter but also the second quarter this year.
High-speed data subs increased by 17,000 in the quarter and our voice lines grew by 38,000. Video customers declined by 19,000 in the quarter for the total company. These improvements were accomplished largely by continuing the strategies which we've been successful with in the past. We've introduced the new Triple Play package, highlighted by a faster high-speed data service, Boost Plus, and we've marketed heavily throughout our operating areas to reinforce the value of our products and services. And our aggressive win-back strategy continues. As of September 30, our win-back total is more than 45% of customers who once tried FiOS. In the Bresnan properties, we saw growth in data and voice customers in the quarter and a slight decline in video subs. Digital penetration is rising as we deploy new and better digital services, and at the end of the third quarter, 75% of Bresnan's basics of drivers were digital. We're on track to complete a fiber ring which will interconnect roughly 85% of the Bresnan customer base by the end of this year. Once completed, we'll be able to essentially manage these geographically diverse systems as one, which will allow us to sell a state-of-the-art Triple Play product across our footprint.
Now let me address some of the new products and offers available in the metro Cablevision footprint. We've recently introduced an offer that includes a new iPod Touch, primarily for win-back situations. Sell-in for the Triple Play package of video, data, and voice is now at 74%, and roughly half of this sell-in is for our new Ultimate Triple Play, which includes a new higher-priced Boost Plus service and a wireless router. We've recently announced an agreement with Turner Networks for all of their Turner to-go content. In a month's time, more than 100,000 customers have registered for this free service. Our customers responded extremely well to our iPad, iPod Touch, and iPhone apps. We currently have 560,000 unique Apple devices using the Optimum app. And we continue to enhance our international programming with 19 new international premium channels launched this year, bringing the total number of international premiums to 86.
Cable capital spending for the quarter was $195 million, including the Bresnan properties. While CPE capital continues to decline, our investments in new products and services have been steady. For the quarter, capital as a percent of revenue was 13.1%. And year-to-date, capital expenditure [ph] was 10.7%. At Optimum Lifepath, business continues to ramp up, with revenue growth of 6% and AOCF growth of 17% for the third quarter versus the prior-year period. At Lightpath, the story has been consistent with the continued pursuit of market share at its core. As an example, we've made great progress in the school sector. In the past year, Lightpath has increased share in the New Jersey Public School District by 26%. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Gregg Seibert for a financial overview.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Let me briefly summarize the financial results for the quarter. Total revenue of $1.67 billion in the third quarter represent an increase of 8% over the prior-year quarter, almost all of which was due to the addition of Bresnan in this yea
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Let me briefly summarize the financial results for the quarter. Total revenue of $1.67 billion in the third quarter represent an increase of 8% over the prior-year quarter, almost all of which was due to the addition of Bresnan in this year's results. Total company AOCF of $539 million represented essentially flat growth compared with the prior-year period. And if you remove the impact of Bresnan properties and Hurricane Irene, AOCF would've actually decreased by 4%. We had a few significant items in the quarter affecting our results, including higher programming costs, and higher sales and marketing, as we continue to aggressively promote our products and services, while revenue growth was essentially flat. 
Free cash flow from continuing operations for the 9 months ended September 30 was $440 million. And that compares with 2010 year-to-date free cash flow of $418 million, an increase of 5%. Free cash flow for the first 9 months of 2011 was $1.53 a share, an 11% increase compared with pro forma free cash flow per share of $1.38 in the prior-year period.
Now turning to leverage and liquidity. At the end of the third quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $180 million. Net debt was $10 billion. At September 30, we had $1.35 billion undrawn and available under the $1.41 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings. In calculating our total company leverage, per our indentures, annual AOCF is determined using a method that's called, the latest quarter annualized. There are no exclusions for items such as the $16 million impact of Hurricane Irene, thus, the hurricane impact translates into a $64 million reduction in AOCF for the purpose of our debt tests. As a result, at September 30, the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.7x. Without the impact of the hurricane, the consolidated ratio would have been approximately 4.5x, which we consider to be a more representative measure of our total company financial leverage.  The CSC Holdings restricted group leverage was 3.2x. At September 30, Bresnan's net debt was approximately $1 billion, with $75 million undrawn and available on its revolving credit facility. The leverage ratio for the quarter was 7x, down from the second quarter ratio of 7.2x. We expect the Bresnan leverage ratio to improve in upcoming quarters as we reach a more steady state of operations and marketing. The Cablevision NOL was $1.6 billion at September 30. We've taken advantage of the bonus depreciation provisions in 2010 and 2011, and intend to do so again in 2012, which extends the timing for our NOL utilization.
Turning to Cablevision's stock repurchase program. In the third quarter, we repurchased approximately 5.4 million shares, totaling $93.9 million. This represents approximately 2% of the company's outstanding shares. From the inception of the program, through the end of September, we've repurchased 27.1 million shares, and our total outstanding Class A shares have decreased from 251 million to 225 million or roughly 10%. At September 30, we had $211 million remaining under our existing repurchase authorization.
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

I thought last quarter, there were a number of one-time items related to the Bresnan integration, and some other sort of onetime costs I thought were going to sort of go away. So can you just spend a little bit of time sort of daisy-chaining this through, sort of the 2Q to 3Q expenses? So we can try and do better job, I guess, going forward.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement, at Bresnan, with a third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-h
componenttext: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement, at Bresnan, with a third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-house this past quarter. Now that resulted in a margin improvement at Bresnan, where we picked up, let's call it roughly 2.7%, 2.8% in the Bresnan margin. And in terms of Cablevision, I don't recall any sort of onetime startup costs or other issues that went away this quarter. As I mentioned in my commentary, certainly, we had higher programming cost. I can't get in, obviously, to the detail on the individual contracts but you can imagine which ones are flowing through this year, as a result of various retransmission, consent processes or negotiations. We had some increases in network management costs, increases in sales and telemarketing cost, and increases in our overall product marketing costs. That's what resulted in the compression of margins this quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I just ask one follow-up? I guess, because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, there's sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going to x growth. Do you think that's
componenttext: Okay. Can I just ask one follow-up? I guess, because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, there's sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going to x growth. Do you think that's a fair characterization? That, sort of, we've seen peak EBITDA? Or do think that's a mischaracterization?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there are definitely cyclical pressures on the business, as there are on a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. And in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued
componenttext: I think there are definitely cyclical pressures on the business, as there are on a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. And in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued opportunity to sell a Triple Play package to residential customers who don't buy today. There's still a considerable amount of satellite penetration in our footprint, which we think is an inferior product at its core. And ultimately, gives us a path to additional residential growth. The business opportunity for continued penetration of telecommunication services in the business environment continues. Even that area is challenged, although growing rapidly in terms of share, you still have a lot of pressure in the business universe, in terms of growth there as well, because of the cyclical situation. And you have the opportunity to continue to shift advertising share on to the cable platform -- through the interactive platform. So I think all of those growth drivers still exist in the business and you have a situation, currently, where you have a pretty slow housing growth -- virtually no housing growth -- and actual reduction in household formation. People moving in with each other. So it's a cyclically challenging time. But the ultimate drivers, I think, is still in the business.

componenttext: A couple of questions, I guess. For Tom, you said you instituted a smaller rate increase than plan. To enhance consumer value, I think, was sort of the point. Are you essentially pricing to the lowest common denominator in your footprint, given the economic cyclicality? Any thoughts as to whether you hope to increase revenue momentum by segmenting more aggressively?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confr
componenttext: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confrontational situation where the World Series was taken off our Cable system. And as that unfolded, and we lost customers, we thought that we should take a less aggressive stance toward a normalized rate increase than we had in the past. And so, we took a smaller rate increase. We then implemented a Boost Plus strategy, where we began to sell-in customers at a higher rate, but we were doing that transactionally. And that continues, in the half of our Triple Play sell-in now is this new Boost product, which has a $10 higher revenue component in it than the previous Triple Play promotional product. So we're moving the subscriber base, but moving it transactionally.

componenttextpreview: Tom, I go back to a conversation you and I had a while back, about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases. I mean, as you've thought through that, is there any
componenttext: Tom, I go back to a conversation you and I had a while back, about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases. I mean, as you've thought through that, is there any way that you think you can sort of reposition the business so that you're not so beholden to the relentless price increases from your video suppliers?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost. And it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways, it's in the ret
componenttext: Well, as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost. And it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways, it's in the retrans  fee itself, it's also in the launch of additional channels and the rates associated with them. And after our last fight with Fox, over the retransmission consent during the World Series last year, Congress got involved and then the FCC actually put out a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. And that process is going on. So we are seeking regulatory relief, regulatory changes that would make that less impactful to our business. And we continue to pursue that.

componenttext: Obviously, programmers, just sell their content the way they do and it is a great distribution model, and it's very attractive for content companies to sell to 100 million homes. And the cable business has been built on that and it's a great business model. My comments were, in terms of Netflix and in terms of it being a pay service and being on television, but I don't expect that the business model that we currently have is about to collapse.

Just curious if you expect to take something away from maybe other, lesser programmers? And can you talk to us a little bit about what's going on marketing costs, kind of what the outlook is? It can be lumpy, but are you at a new, permanently higher level?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to your second question is, no, it is lumpy. And we have some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run, and they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marke
componenttext: Well, the answer to your second question is, no, it is lumpy. And we have some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run, and they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marketing or some new uptick that is permanent. With regard to programming, yes, it is an issue and it is an expensive part of our businesses, it is the single biggest cost item we have. And the fact that retransmission consent became necessary from the eyes of broadcasters, particularly after the '08 recession, has been flowing through our business, and there was a large step up. I think that the overall rate of programming, going forward, will moderate, to some extent, naturally. But right now, we're absorbing the collapse of the broadcast industry business model.

componenttext: Okay. And then just 2 small ones. I know you said, Tom, that the price increase was lower than in previous years because of that Fox dispute. But you did have them, in the New York system, a sequential ARPU decline. Is that all advertising or is it something else?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple, if I could. First of all, in terms of buyback slowing in the quarter versus prior quarters. Is this a run rate we should be looking at or was that really driven by desire to keep leverage at a certain level given the hurricane influence to EBITD
componenttext: A couple, if I could. First of all, in terms of buyback slowing in the quarter versus prior quarters. Is this a run rate we should be looking at or was that really driven by desire to keep leverage at a certain level given the hurricane influence to EBITDA? Secondly, you got the swap expiring next year. Any thoughts on how you plan to handle that, renew it, let it flow, and what the impact of that could be? And third, Tom, as I understand -- i think, as you said -- understand correctly, that you think that occupied homes might actually be declining your footprint?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out, in my comments, that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history here, over a 5-quarter period
componenttext: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out, in my comments, that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history here, over a 5-quarter period, we've retired roughly 10% of our Class A share. So the way I've been looking at the program, and I think we've been thinking about it, has been trying to just, over time, make a significant reduction in the number of outstanding shares. And so I don't -- it's also hard to look at last quarter, or any particular quarter, and declare it be more or less than prior quarters. Because while the absolute dollars change a lot, there have been -- the AMC spend is taking place -- and so the dollars that we had to allocate to repurchase, in the past, reflected the AMC, AOCF also. The constraint that we face right now is our leverage. We're approximately 4.5x after backing out the impact of Hurricane Irene. And even though that number is at the upper end of our normal target range, we're comfortable at that leverage level. We have $200 million remaining of repurchase authorization from our board, and we expect to continue to be opportunistic in looking at repurchases. But one thing that we're not, at this point in time, prepared to do is to ramp up our leverage to buy back additional stock. We are at the upper end of that range, and I think we've been pretty consistent about wanting to stay in that type of a leverage range. On the swap side, yes. Where we have a substantial portion of our interest rate swaps coming off around June 30 of next year. The impact of that is roughly $50 million a year at current interest rates. We haven't made any determination, at this point in time, how much of that we're going to continue to allow to flow, if any, or have made any decision that we're going to go out and re-swap. We continuously look at our capital structure, we've been very focused on extending maturities. And as we get closer to the swaps coming off, we'll certainly make decisions as to where we want to be.

componenttext: And, James, the last question about occupied homes declining. I think the answer is yes. If you measure housing starts and then look at census data on vacancy rates, and our experience confirms it, that people are -- there are actually less occupied dwellings today than there was a year ago.

componenttext: Yes. Well, if you look year-over-year, we've taken that sell-in rate of the Triple Play and the Bresnan property from 19% to 50%. And that's without the completion yet, of the ring, and without the full deployment of all the video product that we want to be fully HD-competitive with satellite. So we think that there's significant upside opportunity in those markets. That's why we purchased those assets. We think that when our full deployment is completed, that we'll have a superior product to all of our competitors in that footprint. And that we'll be able to continue growth and get -- we don't have to make equal Eastern market share to make that thing an attractive investment. But we're rapidly moving up the curve.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been building out a WiFi network, and we've had continuous subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we continue to deploy products, we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full cable
componenttext: Well, we've been building out a WiFi network, and we've had continuous subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we continue to deploy products, we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full cable television service in the home. And we're deploying a new Boost product, with higher speed broadband, which includes a more sophisticated wireless router as part of that package. 70% of our customer base that subscribes to high-speed data, which is 92% of our video base, has a wireless router in their home. So we think WiFi is a major strategic part of our business. We think that we can continue to take advantage of that. We think our video product today, as a result of WiFi, is a superior product to our competitors. All of our competitors. And we think that our data service is enhanced by the WiFi outside the home. And we continue to try to build value for our customers and take market share. Our broadband share remains about 75% and notwithstanding the competition in this marketplace. And this is a more aggressive market, but we have a better broadband product than our competitors, and part about as our WiFi strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Gregg
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us this morning are members of the Cablevision executive team, including Jim Dolan, President and CEO; Tom Rutledge, Chief Operating Officer; Gregg Seibert, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; John Bickham, President of Cable and Communications; and Donna Coleman, Senior Vice President, Financial Planning and Control.  Following a discussion of the company's third quarter 2011 results, we will open the call for questions. If you don't have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please take note of the following: Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results, and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. And let me point out that on Page 5 of today's earnings release, we provide consolidated operations data and a reconciliation of adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF, to operating income.
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, President and CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the third quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 8% to $1.67 billion while AOCF was essentially flat at $539 million when compared to the prior-year period. These results were impacted by Hurricane Irene, as
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good morning. For the third quarter, Cablevision's consolidated revenue grew 8% to $1.67 billion while AOCF was essentially flat at $539 million when compared to the prior-year period. These results were impacted by Hurricane Irene, as well as the addition of the Bresnan properties. Without these 2 items, revenue growth would've been essentially flat and AOCF would've decreased 4% for the quarter. Cablevision generated $440 million in free cash flow from continuing operations over the last 9 months, a 5% improvement over 2010. In addition, the company repurchased more than 5 million shares in the third quarter, and the Board of Directors has approved a quarterly dividend of $0.15 per share, payable in December.
The impact of Hurricane Irene resulted in an extended loss of electricity in a significant part of our footprint in the New York metropolitan area. Cablevision met this challenge well, responding to customers' needs and restoring service quickly. Tom is going to talk, in more detail, about the business and also highlight some positive underlying trends in our performance. These include certain improved subscriber metrics, during a quarter that has historically been seasonally weak for Cablevision, and continued growth at Optimum Lightpath. Not all of our results in the quarter are where we want them. By many measures, we have built the most successful cable television company in the nation, and have set nearly every industry benchmark for sales, customer retention, penetration, and financial performance. Continuing to build upon this historical performance has become more challenging in a highly competitive environment which is compounded by economic pressures, including a significant decline in housing activity. However, we are addressing the challenge and, in many ways, have been preparing for it for several years. We have taken pioneering steps to develop products and enhance our services for our customers without straining their wallets. We have sought and identified new markets that offer attractive growth opportunities to which we allocate a portion of our investable capital. Both Optimum Business and Bresnan exemplify this. And, as importantly, we have aggressively addressed the financial and capital structure of Cablevision to optimize long-term shareholder returns through the refinancing of our balance sheet, the spin-off of MSG and AMC, and the allocation of our investable capital to our quarterly dividend, our stock buyback plan, and highly strategic acquisitions. That said, our primary focus is the continued improvement of our product offerings, the quality of our services, and the provision of the most attractive price value proposition in the market for our customers. Historically, Cablevision has confronted challenges in a constantly involving business over multiple business cycles. We are highly confident that the same spirit of service, innovation, and execution will guide us as we move forward.
We'll now like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Rutledge.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. For the third quarter, Telecom revenue grew by 9% versus the prior year quarter, and AOCF was essentially flat. We suffered hurricane damage in the third quarter, which cost us $16 million. Excluding both the impact of Br
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. For the third quarter, Telecom revenue grew by 9% versus the prior year quarter, and AOCF was essentially flat. We suffered hurricane damage in the third quarter, which cost us $16 million. Excluding both the impact of Bresnan and the hurricane, Telecom AOCF declined by 3.9% in the third quarter over the prior year.
In addition to lack of housing growth, there are several other factors that have impacted the quarter-over-quarter revenue growth for the fiscal year. We had an unusual fourth quarter sub loss last year due to a programming dispute, which led us to take a smaller rate increase in plan to stabilize the customer base over the long term. And Verizon unilaterally reduced voice interconnection fees, which were in the revenue line, and which we are litigating. While our third quarter is seasonally our weakest quarter, we were aided by the launch of new services on the iPod Touch and iPhone, which were integrated into our promotions. In addition, one of our competitors had a strike which hurt their performance. Basic video, data, and voice lines all had net changes, which were an improvement not only of last year's third quarter but also the second quarter this year.
High-speed data subs increased by 17,000 in the quarter and our voice lines grew by 38,000. Video customers declined by 19,000 in the quarter for the total company. These improvements were accomplished largely by continuing the strategies which we've been successful with in the past. We've introduced a new Triple Play package, highlighted by a faster high-speed data service, Boost Plus, and we've marketed heavily throughout our operating areas to reinforce the value of our products and services. And our aggressive win-back strategy continues. As of September 30, our win-back total is more than 45% of customers who once tried FiOS. In the Bresnan properties, we saw growth in data and voice customers in the quarter and a slight decline in video subs. Digital penetration is rising as we deploy new and better digital services, and at the end of the third quarter, 75% of Bresnan's basic subscribers were digital. We're on track to complete a fiber ring which will interconnect roughly 85% of the Bresnan customer base by the end of this year. Once completed, we'll be able to essentially manage these geographically diverse systems as one, which will allow us to sell a state-of-the-art Triple Play product across our footprint.
Now let me address some of the new products and offers available in the metro Cablevision footprint. We've recently introduced an offer that includes a new iPod Touch, primarily for win-back situations. Sell-in for the Triple Play package of video, data, and voice is now at 74%, and roughly half of this sell-in is for our new Ultimate Triple Play, which includes a new higher-priced Boost Plus service and a wireless router. We've recently announced an agreement with Turner Networks for all of their Turner to-go content. In a month's time, more than 100,000 customers have registered for this free service. Our customers responded extremely well to our iPad, iPod Touch, and iPhone apps. We currently have 560,000 unique Apple devices using the Optimum app. And we continue to enhance our international programming with 19 new international premium channels launched this year, bringing the total number of international premiums to 86.
Cable capital spending for the quarter was $195 million, including the Bresnan properties. While CPE capital continues to decline, our investments in new products and services have been steady. For the quarter, capital as a percent of revenue was 13.1%. And year-to-date, capital [indiscernible] was 10.7%. At Optimum Lightpath, business continues to ramp up, with revenue growth of 6% and AOCF growth of 17% for the third quarter versus the prior-year period. At Lightpath, the story has been consistent with the continued pursuit of market share at its core. As an example, we've made great progress in the school sector. In the past year, Lightpath has increased share in the New Jersey Public School District by 26%.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Gregg Seibert for a financial overview.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Let me briefly summarize the financial results for the quarter. Total revenue of $1.67 billion in the third quarter represent an increase of 8% over the prior-year quarter, almost all of which was due to the addition of Bresnan in this yea
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Let me briefly summarize the financial results for the quarter. Total revenue of $1.67 billion in the third quarter represent an increase of 8% over the prior-year quarter, almost all of which was due to the addition of Bresnan in this year's results. Total company AOCF of $539 million represented essentially flat growth compared with the prior-year period. And if you remove the impact of the Bresnan properties and Hurricane Irene, AOCF would've actually decreased by 4%. We had a few significant items in the quarter affecting our results, including higher programming costs, and higher sales and marketing, as we continue to aggressively promote our products and services, while revenue growth was essentially flat.
Free cash flow from continuing operations for the 9 months ended September 30 was $440 million. And that compares with 2010 year-to-date free cash flow of $418 million, an increase of 5%. Free cash flow for the first 9 months of 2011 was $1.53 a share, an 11% increase compared with pro forma free cash flow per share of $1.38 in the prior-year period.
Now turning to leverage and liquidity. At the end of the third quarter, the company's consolidated cash position was $180 million. Net debt was $10 billion. At September 30, we had $1.35 billion undrawn and available under the $1.41 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings. In calculating our total company leverage, per our indentures, annual AOCF is determined using a method that's called, the latest quarter annualized. There are no exclusions for items such as the $16 million impact of Hurricane Irene, thus, the hurricane impact translates into a $64 million reduction in AOCF for the purpose of our debt tests. As a result, at September 30, the company's consolidated leverage ratio was 4.7x. Without the impact of the hurricane, the consolidated ratio would have been approximately 4.5x, which we consider to be a more representative measure of our total company financial leverage. The CSC Holdings restricted group leverage was 3.2x.
At September 30, Bresnan's net debt was approximately $1 billion, with $75 million undrawn and available on its revolving credit facility. The leverage ratio for the quarter was 7x, down from the second quarter ratio of 7.2x. We expect the Bresnan leverage ratio to improve in upcoming quarters as we reach a more steady state of operations and marketing. The Cablevision NOL was $1.6 billion at September 30. We've taken advantage of the bonus depreciation provisions in 2010 and 2011, and intend to do so again in 2012, which extends the timing for our NOL utilization.
Turning to Cablevision's stock repurchase program. In the third quarter, we repurchased approximately 5.4 million shares, totaling $93.9 million. This represents approximately 2% of the company's outstanding shares. From the inception of the program, through the end of September, we've repurchased 27.1 million shares, and our total outstanding Class A shares have decreased from 251 million to 225 million or roughly 10%. At September 30, we had $211 million remaining under our existing repurchase authorization.
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jason Bazinet of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jason Bazinet of Citi.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just had a question regarding the sequential change in EBITDA. I thought last quarter, there were a number of one-time items related to the Bresnan integration, and some other sort of onetime costs I thought were going to sort of go away. So can you jus
componenttext: I just had a question regarding the sequential change in EBITDA. I thought last quarter, there were a number of one-time items related to the Bresnan integration, and some other sort of onetime costs I thought were going to sort of go away. So can you just spend a little bit of time sort of daisy-chaining this through, sort of the 2Q to 3Q expenses? So we can try and do better job, I guess, going forward.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement, at Bresnan, with a third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-h
componenttext: Well, Jason, I don't know that we had onetime items for Bresnan last quarter. I think what was discussed on the conference call was the termination of an interconnection agreement, at Bresnan, with a third party provider. And indeed, we did take that in-house this past quarter. Now that resulted in a margin improvement at Bresnan, where we picked up, let's call it roughly 2.7%, 2.8% in the Bresnan margin. And in terms of Cablevision, I don't recall any sort of onetime startup costs or other issues that went away this quarter. As I mentioned in my commentary, certainly, we had higher programming cost. I can't get in, obviously, to the detail on the individual contracts but you can imagine which ones are flowing through this year, as a result of various retransmission, consent processes or negotiations. And we had some increases in network management costs, increases in sales and telemarketing cost, and increases in our overall product marketing costs. That's what resulted in the compression of margins this quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I just ask one follow-up? I guess then, because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, there's sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going x growth. Do you think that
componenttext: Okay. Can I just ask one follow-up? I guess then, because you guys are sort of maybe 2 years ahead of the rest of the industry, there's sort of growing concern among the investor community about sort of the whole industry going x growth. Do you think that's a fair characterization? That, sort of, we've seen peak EBITDA? Or do think that's a mischaracterization?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there are definitely cyclical pressures on the business, as there are on a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. And in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued
componenttext: I think there are definitely cyclical pressures on the business, as there are on a lot of businesses. But over the long-term, I think the business still has a lot of growth in it. And in the areas where we thought there would be growth, there is continued opportunity to sell a Triple Play package to residential customers who don't buy it today. There's still a considerable amount of satellite penetration in our footprint, which we think is an inferior product at its core. And ultimately, gives us a path to additional residential growth. The business opportunity for continued penetration of telecommunication services in the business environment continues. Even that area is challenged, although growing rapidly in terms of share, you still have a lot of pressure in the business universe, in terms of growth there as well, because of the cyclical situation. And you have the opportunity to continue to shift advertising share on to the cable platform -- through the interactive platform. So I think all of those growth drivers still exist in the business and you have a situation, currently, where you have a pretty slow housing growth -- virtually no housing growth -- and actual reduction in household formation. People are moving in with each other. So it's a cyclically challenging time. But the ultimate drivers, I think, are still in the business.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Phil Cusick of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Phil Cusick of JPMorgan.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Wonder if can you talk a little bit about -- how you're thinking about fourth quarter. You talked, specifically, about Verizon having some challenges in the third quarter. As they get more aggressive, as they've talked about, during -- in the fourth quart
componenttext: Wonder if can you talk a little bit about -- how you're thinking about fourth quarter. You talked, specifically, about Verizon having some challenges in the third quarter. As they get more aggressive, as they've talked about, during -- in the fourth quarter. Do you expect sort of a typical seasonal rebound here or should we temper that a little bit?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't want to give you a prediction on the fourth quarter. We're talking about the third quarter today. But in terms of Verizon's behavior, they were challenged in the third quarter. They were also very aggressive in the second quarter, which I think wa
componenttext: I don't want to give you a prediction on the fourth quarter. We're talking about the third quarter today. But in terms of Verizon's behavior, they were challenged in the third quarter. They were also very aggressive in the second quarter, which I think was done in anticipation of the third quarter situation. So when you look at it over the whole year, their performance is fairly consistent with prior years.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, I guess. For Tom, you said you instituted a smaller rate increase than plan. To enhance consumer value, I think, was sort of the point. Are you essentially pricing to the lowest common denominator in your footprint, given the econom
componenttext: A couple of questions, I guess. For Tom, you said you instituted a smaller rate increase than plan. To enhance consumer value, I think, was sort of the point. Are you essentially pricing to the lowest common denominator in your footprint, given the economic cyclicality? Any thoughts as to whether you hope to increase revenue momentum by segmenting more aggressively?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confr
componenttext: Well, we have a variety of product offers. And we have a variety of customers who choose different packages. So we do that through our selling and retention process all the time. But we had a challenge in the fourth quarter of last year, with a very confrontational situation where the World Series was taken off our Cable system. And as that unfolded, and we lost customers, we thought that we should take a less aggressive stance toward a normalized rate increase than we had in the past. And so, we took a smaller rate increase. We then implemented a Boost Plus strategy, where we began to sell-in customers at a higher rate, but we were doing that transactionally. And that continues, and the half of our Triple Play sell-in now is this new Boost product, which has a $10 higher revenue component in it than the previous Triple Play promotional product. So we're moving the subscriber base, but moving it transactionally.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. I misunderstood your comments as relating to a new rate increase, not the pace of last year's rate increase. So that's helpful. When you indicated Verizon unilaterally reducing their connect fees, any chance you can give us a sense of
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. I misunderstood your comments as relating to a new rate increase, not the pace of last year's rate increase. So that's helpful. When you indicated Verizon unilaterally reducing their connect fees, any chance you can give us a sense of what the revenue impact was for the quarter from that?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Approximately $4 million.
componenttext: Approximately $4 million.
