headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of Bernstein.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, I go back to a conversation you and I had a while back, about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases. I mean, as you've thought through that, is there any
componenttext: Tom, I go back to a conversation you and I had a while back, about sort of how you can think about reinventing the business a little bit. To try to get out of the way of the programming cost increases. I mean, as you've thought through that, is there any way that you think you can sort of reposition the business so that you're not so beholden to the relentless price increases from your video suppliers?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost. And it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways, it's in the ret
componenttext: Well, as you know, we had filed a request to have the SEC help us in the retransmission consent fight, which has a lot of impact on the overall programming cost. And it actually gets monetized by programming companies in a variety of ways, it's in the retrans fee itself, it's also in the launch of additional channels and the rates associated with them. And after our last fight with Fox, over the retransmission consent during the World Series last year, Congress got involved and then the FCC actually put out a proposed -- a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. And that process is going on. So we are seeking regulatory relief, regulatory changes that would make that less impactful to our business. And we continue to pursue that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there any other -- as you think about the cable networks, and that sort of thing, is there, whether it's -- you've talked about some comments that are more receptive to à la carte, for example, than the rest of the industry. Is there anything you can
componenttext: Are there any other -- as you think about the cable networks, and that sort of thing, is there, whether it's -- you've talked about some comments that are more receptive to à la carte, for example, than the rest of the industry. Is there anything you can actually do to make progress on that front or is that more just voicing your interest in the concept but it's practically hard to get to?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there is, obviously, programmers choose to sell their content the way they do and it is a great distribution model, and it's very attractive for content companies to sell to 100 million homes. And the cable business has been built on that and it's a
componenttext: Well, there is, obviously, programmers choose to sell their content the way they do and it is a great distribution model, and it's very attractive for content companies to sell to 100 million homes. And the cable business has been built on that and it's a great business model. My comments were, in terms of Netflix and in terms of it being a pay service and being on television, but I don't expect that the business model that we currently have is about to collapse.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jessica Reif-Cohen from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jessica Reif-Cohen from Bank of America.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. On the, I guess, for Gregg or Tom. On the cost side, I mean, the programming stuff as we can see from previous questions, I mean, retrans isn't going away. Just curious if you expect to take something away from maybe other, l
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. On the, I guess, for Gregg or Tom. On the cost side, I mean, the programming stuff as we can see from previous questions, I mean, retrans isn't going away. Just curious if you expect to take something away from maybe other, lesser programmers? And can you talk to us a little bit about what's going on marketing costs? What -- kind of what the outlook is? It can be lumpy, but are you at a new, permanently higher level?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to your second question is, no, it is lumpy. And we have some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run, and they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marke
componenttext: Well, the answer to your second question is, no, it is lumpy. And we have some new product offers and some new marketing campaigns that we wanted to run, and they just happened to be in the third quarter. So I wouldn't say that there's a new cost of marketing or some new uptick that is permanent. With regard to programming, yes, it is an issue and it is an expensive part of our businesses, it is the single biggest cost item we have. And the fact that retransmission consent became necessary from the eyes of broadcasters, particularly after the '08 recession, has been flowing through our business, and there was a large step up. I think that the overall rate of programming, going forward, will moderate, to some extent, naturally. But right now, we're absorbing the collapse of the broadcast industry business model.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just 2 small ones. I know you said, Tom, that the price increase was lower than in previous years because of the Fox dispute. But you did have then, in the New York system, a sequential ARPU decline. Is that all advertising or is it somethi
componenttext: Okay. And then just 2 small ones. I know you said, Tom, that the price increase was lower than in previous years because of the Fox dispute. But you did have then, in the New York system, a sequential ARPU decline. Is that all advertising or is it something else?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's mostly advertising and it's mostly the change in political advertising. Our actual advertising ads in political is up.
componenttext: It's mostly advertising and it's mostly the change in political advertising. Our actual advertising ads in political is up.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I was wondering if you can say how much it was up. And the last question I have is -- Jim mentioned, in his opening comments, strategic acquisition. I was just wondering if you could give us some color on what you would be thinking about.
componenttext: And then I was wondering if you can say how much it was up. And the last question I have is -- Jim mentioned, in his opening comments, strategic acquisition. I was just wondering if you could give us some color on what you would be thinking about.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: At this point, Jessica, there's -- we don't comment on specific acquisitions. There's nothing on the radar screen. We certainly would look, if given an opportunity, to do things like, potentially, add a little bit to Lightpath in our market. But those ten
componenttext: At this point, Jessica, there's -- we don't comment on specific acquisitions. There's nothing on the radar screen. We certainly would look, if given an opportunity, to do things like, potentially, add a little bit to Lightpath in our market. But those tend to be relatively smaller acquisitions. And at this point we're focused on operating the business; we're not focused on getting bigger at this point in time.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple, if I could. First of all, in terms of buyback slowing in the quarter versus prior quarters. Is this the sort of run rate we should be looking at or was that really driven by desire to keep leverage at a certain level given the hurricane influenc
componenttext: A couple, if I could. First of all, in terms of buyback slowing in the quarter versus prior quarters. Is this the sort of run rate we should be looking at or was that really driven by desire to keep leverage at a certain level given the hurricane influence to EBITDA? Secondly, you got the swap expiring next year. Any thoughts on how you plan to handle that, renew it, let it float, and what the impact of that could be? And third, Tom, as I understand, I think, as you said -- understand correctly, that you think that occupied homes might actually be declining your footprint?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out, in my comments, that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history here, over a 5-quarter period
componenttext: Let me take the easy question first, which is the share repurchase. One of the reasons I pointed out, in my comments, that we've retired 2% of the outstanding shares this quarter is that if you go back and look at the history here, over a 5-quarter period, we've retired roughly 10% of our Class A share. So the way I've been looking at the program, and I think we've been thinking about it, has been trying to just, over time, make a significant reduction in the number of outstanding shares. And so I don't -- it's also hard to look at last quarter, or any particular quarter, and declare it be more or less than prior quarters. Because while the absolute dollars change a lot, there have been -- the AMC spend is taking place and so the dollars that we had to allocate to repurchase, in the past, reflected the AMC, AOCF also. The constraint that we face right now is our leverage. We're approximately 4.5x after backing out the impact of Hurricane Irene. And even though that number is at the upper end of our normal target range, we're comfortable at that leverage level. We have $200 million remaining of repurchase authorization from our board, and we expect to continue to be opportunistic in looking at repurchases. But one thing that we're not, at this point in time, prepared to do, is to ramp up our leverage to buy back additional stock. We are at the upper end of that range, and I think we've been pretty consistent about wanting to stay in that type of a leverage range. On the swap side, yes. Where we have a substantial portion of our interest rate swaps coming off around June 30 of next year, the impact of that is roughly $50 million a year at current interest rates. We haven't made any determination, at this point in time, how much of that we're going to continue to allow to float, if any, or have we made any decision that we're going to go out and re-swap. We continuously look at our capital structure, we've been very focused on extending maturities. And as we get closer to the swaps coming off, we'll certainly make decisions as to where we want to be.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, James, the last question about occupied homes declining. I think the answer is yes. If you measure housing starts and then look at census data on vacancy rates, and our experience confirms it, that people are -- there are actually less occupied dwell
componenttext: And, James, the last question about occupied homes declining. I think the answer is yes. If you measure housing starts and then look at census data on vacancy rates, and our experience confirms it, that people are -- there are actually less occupied dwellings today than there was a year ago.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you think your penetration of sort of addressable markets, being kind of occupied homes, is declining as it is, from a video basis, of total homes or do you think you're reasonably stable on that front?
componenttext: Do you think your penetration of sort of addressable markets, being kind of occupied homes, is declining as it is, from a video basis, of total homes or do you think you're reasonably stable on that front?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Reasonably stable, I think.
componenttext: Reasonably stable, I think.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Actually, our strategies for marketing were in place before we knew about their strike situation and had nothing to do with it. It's coincidence. Their second quarter pricing was very aggressive, the most aggressive we've seen and it's more aggressi
componenttext: Okay. Actually, our strategies for marketing were in place before we knew about their strike situation and had nothing to do with it. It's coincidence. Their second quarter pricing was very aggressive, the most aggressive we've seen and it's more aggressive than their current fourth quarter pricing.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So they've become -- they've backed up a little bit?
componenttext: Okay. So they've become -- they've backed up a little bit?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're still very aggressive though. I don't want to imply otherwise.
componenttext: They're still very aggressive though. I don't want to imply otherwise.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Understood. And they're still not requiring any contract or anything like that?
componenttext: Understood. And they're still not requiring any contract or anything like that?

componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, just on the commercial side. Obviously, we can see the Lightpath numbers, but we've seen pretty good growth out of the "SME" business from Time Warner Cable and I think expectations are pretty high for Comcast and Charter. You guys, like your re
componenttext: And then, just on the commercial side. Obviously, we can see the Lightpath numbers, but we've seen pretty good growth out of the "SME" business from Time Warner Cable and I think expectations are pretty high for Comcast and Charter. You guys, like your residential business, I think were ahead of the industry in growing that business. But could you just spend maybe a second on how that business is growing now? It's sort of buried, I think, in your cable segment. But any sense of revenue growth or market share or outlook that you could help us out with?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, our current advertising is that more people choose us than Verizon for their business services. So we think we have the majority of the share now in the small business marketplace. And we see continued share opportunities, particularly as we move up
componenttext: Well, our current advertising is that more people choose us than Verizon for their business services. So we think we have the majority of the share now in the small business marketplace. And we see continued share opportunities, particularly as we move up market into the mid-market. And there are still major portions of the mid-market available to us in terms of share growth.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011

componenttext: This is actually Stephan Bisson on for Marcy. I just had 2 questions. First, do you expect any hurricane expenses to rollover to Q4 at all or is that all done?

componenttextpreview: Minimal.
componenttext: Minimal.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Minimal, okay. And then the second question, relating to Bresnan. When that ring is actually done, you guys can offer more bundled services and that type of stuff. Do you believe that those markets are kind of -- do they really want those services? Obviou
componenttext: Minimal, okay. And then the second question, relating to Bresnan. When that ring is actually done, you guys can offer more bundled services and that type of stuff. Do you believe that those markets are kind of -- do they really want those services? Obviously, you think so because you're building out. But any kind of estimate as to what kind of penetration you could expect relative to the core New York business?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, if you look year-over-year, we've taken the sell-in rate of the Triple Play and the Bresnan property from 19% to 50%. And that's without the completion yet, of the ring, and without the full deployment of all the video product that we want to b
componenttext: Yes. Well, if you look year-over-year, we've taken the sell-in rate of the Triple Play and the Bresnan property from 19% to 50%. And that's without the completion yet, of the ring, and without the full deployment of all the video product that we want to be fully HD-competitive with satellite. So we think that there's significant upside opportunity in those markets. That's why we purchased those assets. We think that when our full deployment is completed, that we'll have a superior product to all of our competitors in that footprint. And that we'll be able to continue growth and get -- we don't have to make equal Eastern market share to make that thing an attractive investment. But we're rapidly moving up the curve.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Joyce of Miller Tabak + Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Joyce of Miller Tabak + Co.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could please update on your thinking for wireless strategy, given that you've got some increasing exposure to iPad apps and what have you.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could please update on your thinking for wireless strategy, given that you've got some increasing exposure to iPad apps and what have you.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been building out a WiFi network, and we've had continuous subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we've continued to deploy products, we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full ca
componenttext: Well, we've been building out a WiFi network, and we've had continuous subscriber utilization increases in that network. And we've continued to deploy products, we now have more than half a million devices out there that can use WiFi and watch our full cable television service in the home. And we're deploying a new Boost product, with higher speed broadbands, which includes a more sophisticated wireless router as part of that package. 70% of our customer base that subscribes to high-speed data, which is 92% of our video base, has a wireless router in their home. So we think WiFi is a major strategic part of our business. We think that we can continue to take advantage of that. We think our video product today, as a result of WiFi, is a superior product to our competitors, all of our competitors. And we think that our data service is enhanced by the WiFi outside the home. And we continue to try to build value for our customers and take market share. Our broadband share remains at about 75% and notwithstanding the competition in this marketplace. And this is a more aggressive market, but we have a better broadband product than our competitors, and part about as our WiFi strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if I could tack on to that, the capital expenditures question, with the flooding in Thailand. Do you see any disruption to any components in the next few quarters? Would it be somehow disruptive to your provisioning or build outs?
componenttext: And if I could tack on to that, the capital expenditures question, with the flooding in Thailand. Do you see any disruption to any components in the next few quarters? Would it be somehow disruptive to your provisioning or build outs?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have to admit, nobody has come to me with that crisis. I'm not aware of the problem. So it hasn't shown up at my radar.
componenttext: I have to admit, nobody has come to me with that crisis. I'm not aware of the problem. So it hasn't shown up at my radar.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tom Eagan of Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tom Eagan of Collins Stewart.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, you're talking about building value for your customers, by not charging them for any of these new features. Could you give us a sense of what you see in terms of any reduction in churn? Whether it be on video or data or price or on voice. And then I
componenttext: Tom, you're talking about building value for your customers, by not charging them for any of these new features. Could you give us a sense of what you see in terms of any reduction in churn? Whether it be on video or data or price or on voice. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said earlier, we're in a very competitive environment. It's also challenged by a cyclical downturn in housing. But in light of all of that, we are holding our customer base fairly well. We are, actually, charging for some of the enhancements.
componenttext: Well, as we said earlier, we're in a very competitive environment. It's also challenged by a cyclical downturn in housing. But in light of all of that, we are holding our customer base fairly well. We are, actually, charging for some of the enhancements. As I said, we're marketing our way in with Boost Plus. Half of our Triple Play acquisitions are taking that product. That does cost more. And so our churn, on an annual basis, is flat year-over-year. And in light of the situation, economically, we think that that's pretty decent.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. Then, across the sector, we've seen a slowing in the phone adds in the home, I guess, this quarter. Could you share with us what you're seeing in your systems? And, for example, you're seeing any increase in the wireless substitution? Any pla
componenttext: Right. Okay. Then, across the sector, we've seen a slowing in the phone adds in the home, I guess, this quarter. Could you share with us what you're seeing in your systems? And, for example, you're seeing any increase in the wireless substitution? Any plans you're thinking about to change, whether it's the marketing the pricing?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our Triple Play sell-in continues to go up. So we priced the phone service appropriately, and to some extent, that has retarded wireless substitution of wire line phones in our marketplace.
componenttext: Our Triple Play sell-in continues to go up. So we priced the phone service appropriately, and to some extent, that has retarded wireless substitution of wire line phones in our marketplace.

componenttext: Operator, we'll take one more call, one more question.

componenttext: Your final question comes from Bryan Kraft of Evercore Partners.

componenttext: Can you quantify the revenue impact, from credits, for service outages and also from software advertising during Hurricane Irene and the aftermath? And also, the political advertising in last year's third quarter? And then, also, I don't know if you give us a sense as to how much higher marketing was in the third quarter, either in dollars or as a percentage of revenue, relative to say what a normal run rate would be.

componenttext: Some credits were actually fairly immaterial. And I don't have the other information that you asked for. I'm sorry.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, maybe I could follow up. I mean, it's kind of related to a previous question about, has there been a permanent structural change in the margin structure at Cablevision because of higher spending on marketing and programming. I mean, is, while it
componenttext: I guess, maybe I could follow up. I mean, it's kind of related to a previous question about, has there been a permanent structural change in the margin structure at Cablevision because of higher spending on marketing and programming. I mean, is, while it may have been higher than normal, is there, going forward, maybe a higher percentage of revenue that's going to be allocated toward marketing? Or is it, more or less, going to revert back to where we were before the third quarter?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our margin is a percentage of revenue, and our revenue growth, was low for the reasons that I explained earlier. And the programming and other operating cost increases were more consistent with prior periods and not that unusual. But coupled with a low re
componenttext: Our margin is a percentage of revenue, and our revenue growth, was low for the reasons that I explained earlier. And the programming and other operating cost increases were more consistent with prior periods and not that unusual. But coupled with a low revenue growth environment, the margins declined. And I explained what I thought the factors driving our revenue change this year was, including the go-in numbers, the rate increase, the Verizon reduction.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2011

componenttext: Thank you all for joining us today. That concludes our call.
